—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to his statement in parliament that `We do not utter rhetoric. We deliver on promises we have made'. Since June 1987 the home mortgage interest rate has increased from 15.5 per cent to at least 17 per cent. Now that the Prime Minister has received a resounding message from the electorate in South Australia, I ask him what action he proposes to take--
—You came second again, Andrew.
—To fulfil his promise made to the Australian people in his policy speech on 23 June 1987 that `under Labor interest rates will continue to fall'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the obvious point at the beginning of my answer to the question-it was made by way of interjection from the Government benches-that I have publicly acknowledged a message from the South Australian election, and I acknowledge it here, and that is interest rates are hurting and people do not like them. Obviously to some extent an outstanding Premier, Mr Bannon-I remind honourable members that he is still the Premier of South Australia-has paid some penalty for the hurt that is being felt. I have public knowledge of that message. I have not noticed any acknowledgment by the Leader of the Opposition of an equally resounding message which has been given to the Liberals, and that is, the people of Australia will not buy them at any price. They have a great record for coming second.

ANSWER.PARA: I continue to be amazed, as we on this side of the House are, by the Opposition Leader's absolutely breathtaking hypocrisy on the question of interest rates. He does not acknowledge the fact that under the previous Government interest rates were higher than they are under this Government. He might have a bit more credibility if he faced up to and answered questions about the interest rate implications of the Opposition's Economic Action Plan. As I have said before in this place, and as I repeat in the context of the Leader of the Opposition's question, the Opposition needs to face up to what the interest rate implications are of the alternative to the Government's policy. I have stated quite clearly why interest rates are where they are. They are there for very sound reasons which I have explained. It is about time that the Leader of the Opposition faced up to the fact that under the Opposition's so-called Economic Action Plan interest rates would be higher.

Let us make it quite clear that the Opposition has acknowledged that there will be no tightening of fiscal policy under its Economic Action Plan. Indeed, its fiscal position would be significantly looser because of the enormous hole in the revenue side which would flow from its abolition of the capital gains tax. If we look at the wages arm of policy, every commentator acknowledges that there would be a massive blow-out in wages under the so-called Economic Action Plan. If we have a looser fiscal policy and wages policy, as the Opposition would have, the absolute alternative, the inescapable conclusion, is that interest rates would be higher. That is a fact which is acknowledged by all commentators who have analysed the Opposition's economic policy.

It is simply about time that the Leader of the Opposition came clean on the hidden agenda of the Opposition in this. The hidden agenda is as it was in 1981-82-massive unemployment. We cannot have any other outcome if we have looser fiscal policy and a situation then of a wages blow-out. The inevitable policy is tighter interest rates and massive unemployment. One does not have to be theoretical about it. This was precisely the prescription the Opposition had in 1981-82, and it will not come clean on it. What the Opposition is trying to do this week, in going to interest rates, is do the dirty work for its Queensland colleagues. It will not divert the attention of the Queensland electorate from the single issue of the Queensland election, and that is the massive corruption which has pervaded the State of Queensland under coalition Liberal and National governments for the last 30 years and the Nationals in the last period. That is the issue, and the Opposition will not divert attention from it.

Finally, I suggest to the Leader of the Opposition that if he believes that our analysis of his Economic Action Plan is incorrect, if we are wrong in saying that necessarily the Opposition would have higher interest rates and massive unemployment, why does he not present himself to a press conference so that he can explain, in answer to questions from the press, where our analysis of the Opposition's Economic Action Plan is wrong? The fact is that the Opposition has got the Leader of the Opposition totally on a leash and is terrified to let him off the leash to be exposed to questioning by the press.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Treasurer aware of recent commentary that Australia's capital gains tax is out of line with those found in other countries? During his recent visit to Japan and the United Kingdom, what information has the Treasurer gathered on capital gains taxation in those countries?
—Order! The honourable member for Dundas will cease interjecting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In general, what I found in those countries is that they are strengthening their capital gains tax regimes, and there is no debate about capital gains taxation. The only country in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) that I am aware of that has a public debate about capital gains is Australia-and it is only a public issue because of the squalid policies of the Opposition. I am aware that in his address to the annual general meeting of Elders-IXL Ltd in Adelaide on 15 November Mr John Elliott, the Chairman, said:

ANSWER.PARA: Australia's punitive capital gains tax runs counter to tax policies around the world.

This was said on the same day that the shadow Treasurer released his discredited 29-page defence of the Opposition proposal-which, I might add, has since disappeared without trace. It was part of an orchestrated Liberal Party strategy to undermine the overwhelming public support for the capital gains tax. But of course, like everything else the Liberals are saying about capital gains, Mr Elliott's claims should be seen for what they are: a bit of self-serving rubbish.

Let me deal with some of these other countries and just demonstrate how the proposal by the Liberal Party and its Chairman is nothing more than an attempt to find an economic rationale for ripping the guts out of a decent tax. The United Kingdom strengthened its capital gains tax in the 1988 budget. It now taxes real capital gains in excess of a small personal threshold which was reduced in that budget and it taxes them at full marginal rates of tax. In Japan, nominal capital gains have been taxable since 1946, but there have recently been changes to Japan's capital gains tax which have toughened its impact, particularly in relation to securities. In the United States, capital gains have been taxable since 1913, but under the Tax Reform Act 1986, which took effect from 1987, the distinction between short and long term capital gains was removed and full nominal gains are now taxed at full marginal rates. They are not taxed at concessional rates as they used to be--

TALK.START.PARA: —But they give full deductability for home loan interest.
—If the honourable member for Dundas interjects again I will deal with him.

—They are now taxed at full marginal rates. There is a proposal presently before the United States Senate to lower the tax rates on capital gains for a short period in an attempt to bring forward revenue to combat the large US budget deficit, by encouraging taxpayers to sell assets. But the proposal is that the tax rates should then return to full marginal rates and that only the real capital gains be taxed. In other words, they would return to a situation exactly the same as occurs in Australia-that is, a tax at the full marginal rate on the real gain. In Canada capital gains have been taxable since 1972 but, as in other countries, the provisions have recently been strengthened. Until 1987 one-half of nominal capital gains were taxed at full marginal rates. This proportion is being increased to 75 per cent of nominal capital gains by 1990. I am unaware of any OECD country which has a capital gains tax as ineffectual as what is being proposed by the Opposition in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: In other countries capital gains taxation is, as I said at the beginning of my answer, simply not an issue. It was not an issue until it was raised by the Liberal Party of Australia in the current debate. The Opposition proposal has nothing whatsoever to do with what is happening in other countries, contrary to Mr Elliott's claim. It is simply a self-serving intervention by Mr Elliott to defend the indefensible with a capital gains tax change which would do nothing other than line the pockets of wealthy people like himself and look after the one per cent of taxpayers who currently pay capital gains tax.

As I have said in the House before, the proposal by the Opposition would amount to the largest transfer of wealth in the history of the nation to one per cent of the taxpaying population in what would be an inequitable and, worse than that, economically destructive policy change which would make the tax system lopsided and favour investment in speculative capital activity. As one writer said recently, the great problem with the Liberal Party is that it does not know how to run a market system. It thinks that to run a market system one has to glad-hand business and throw money at it rather than running an efficient system, an efficient economy, where resources are allocated properly and where income is taxed regardless of its variety, which is what the capital gains tax is all about. I conclude by making the point that Mr Elliott's statement is nothing but self-serving rubbish which has been echoed by his parliamentary yes men in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Treasurer categorically deny that, as part of a review of options for housing for the next election, Treasury officers are investigating an option to extend the capital gains tax to the family home in return for tax deductability of interest?
—Yes, I categorically deny it.

—Is the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy aware of the motion passed at the recent National Farmers Federation conference calling for the exclusion of all plant and animal products that have any risk of carrying disease and calling for a review of quarantine measures to provide total protection for Australian plant and animal industries? Can the Minister advise the House whether the Government intends to undertake such a review?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Rankin for his question. I would have expected that, by now, with the Opposition beating up the question of quarantine, it might have asked a question about it in this House. The thing that has occasioned most of the recent display of histrionics by the Opposition is the lifting of the ban on the import of Canadian pig meat. I would rather address the more basic quarantine principle. In 1987 I established the Lindsay Quarantine Review Committee to undertake a review of quarantine policies to ensure that we have the best possible methods of assessing quarantine risk and using our resources most effectively in countering those risks. The Lindsay Committee advised-and I entirely agree with it-that we cannot have a no-risk or nil-risk quarantine policy. There is no such thing as no risk. More importantly, to try to have a no-risk policy would place an intolerable burden on our economy. We would have to ban people, postal articles, aircraft, ships and all forms of seed and genetic material from coming into Australia. The policy we have adopted involves a formal, transparent decision-making process based on assessed risks with significant input from industry in the making of decisions on the allocation of resources. In other words, it is exactly the same policy framework that we have had in place for 10 years but, post-Lindsay, we have actually tightened the policy. Through a series of steps, we now take into account the pest or disease threat, where it comes from, how it spreads and its biological consequences. We also take into account the strategies for exclusion and the risks of entry under those strategies. We take into account, too, the costs and benefits of continued exclusion. In this way we can build up profiles of pests and diseases we want to keep out of the country. For example, the profile of foot and mouth shows that it must be kept out of the country. At the other end of the spectrum, there are lesser diseases and pests that do not justify the measures foot and mouth justifies.

ANSWER.PARA: As a matter of fact, one of our biggest problems is smuggling. Recently we had the nashi budwood incident. We have had a series of chicken diseases and we have also had the illegal importation of grapevines. Smuggling is probably the biggest problem we have in quarantine. The Government's approach post-Lindsay, the tightening up, does not mean the abandonment of a strong quarantine policy. We are not opening the floodgates to disease, as maintained by the Opposition; on the contrary, we are shutting them firmly. We know that there will always be an element of risk: we are acknowledging that risk and we are quantifying it. We are using it to make decisions rather than pretending it is not there. If continued prohibition of a product cannot be justified on quarantine grounds, we will not use quarantine as a non-tariff barrier.

Logic does not seem to worry the Opposition, which is running around scaring people and implying that it is possible to run a no-risk quarantine policy. The Opposition's hypocrisy on this issue is exposed in its so-called economic policy, which promises a $14m or 23 per cent cut to the budget of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it does not.

—The honourable member ought to read his own document. What would that do to our quarantine preparedness? It would mean a fingers crossed approach with late responses and higher costs placed on Australia's entire agricultural sector, which would be at risk.
—My question is to the Prime Minister.
—Have you found any gold in Coronation Hill yet?

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is the Minister aware of the paper by the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) entitled Measuring Poverty? What are the implications of the report for social and economic policy development into the 1990s?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Streeton for his question. The Government welcomes the EPAC report, which points out that over the past 20 years the problem of poverty in Australia has increasingly been associated with homelessness, long-term unemployment, youth unemployment, marriage breakdown and hardship amongst immigrants and refugees. It points out also that, as a result of the Government's reforms, such as the family allowance supplement, rent assistance and pension indexation, poverty is now less a problem of inadequate income but a problem of more complex issues relating to alienation and exclusion from full participation in society. The report concludes:

ANSWER.PARA: Income support measures alone are not sufficient to deal with the broader aspects of poverty that exist in the Australian community. A broader range of other social policies will also be necessary.

The paper points out the need for a much broader approach to research into poverty-an approach that analyses the nature of deprivation and exclusion experienced by different groups. The House will recall that on 6 March this year I referred to the importance of social wage measures such as Medicare, superannuation, Austudy and family payments and of programs like Newstart and JET-jobs, education and training-which provide assistance for the excluded and disadvantaged. As the Prime Minister stated in his address to the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) congress in September:

It is possible to describe poverty in terms of dollars and cents or the lack of them. It is possible to attack it in terms of financial benchmarks, as we have done. But the causes and the symptoms of poverty are far wider than pure economics. Perhaps we need a broader assault-ACOSS can help-along with State and local governments who have major interests in many aspects of this problem.

The Australian Labor Party will continue in its social policy development to address the problems raised by EPAC. If it is clear that we have developed policies that have attacked the root of income insecurity and poverty and that we are prepared to build on those policies of the previous Government which excluded hundreds of thousands of people from the labour market, it is also clear that coalition policies stand in very stark contrast to the Government's commitment to overcome poverty and disadvantage.

The Opposition would deny access to the universal program of health care. As I understand it, it would freeze the number of child-care places. It would certainly prevent any further growth in higher education. It would abolish programs that help families living in the bush-programs like Countrylink, the rural education access program, and the rural women's access grants program. It would slash the mechanisms to support families in times of crisis. Programs such as Skillshare, Jobstart, Newstart and JET, under a coalition policy, would effectively be abolished. So, in contrast to the Government's efforts in line with EPAC's recommendation to broaden the analysis of poverty to include broader social conditions, the Government's acceptance of the thrust of that approach, the very strong social programs that have been developed, and our improvements in terms of income support, the Opposition would tear into those programs. It would lock people into disadvantage and leave them excluded rather than help to build social policies that in the long run remove the cancer of poverty from the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the Treasurer's interview reported in the Australian today in which he refers to changes on the waterfront as `small beer'. I ask the Prime Minister how waterfront reform can be small beer, given that the Industries Assistance Commission has estimated that a 20 per cent improvement in the labour productivity in the water transport industry as a whole, combined with a faster turnaround of ships in port, would produce an initial cost saving of $860m in 1986-87 dollars, leading to an increase of over $1 billion in gross domestic product in the longer term.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I have not read the report of the interview to which the honourable gentleman refers. I would have thought it very unlikely that the observations made by the shadow Treasurer would be a full reflection of everything that the Treasurer has to say about the matter, but I have not read the report of the interview. If the honourable gentleman would like to find out from the Treasurer the totality of his view about reform on the waterfront within the general program of micro-economic reform, there is a simple way for him to do so. After the next question, he could address a question to the Treasurer who, more than likely, would tell him.
—Is it small beer or not?
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—I simply make the point that I have not seen the report and I refuse to accept that what the shadow Treasurer has put to me is representative of all that the Treasurer has had to say on or thinks about this subject. It would be quite pointless therefore to respond to it.

ANSWER.PARA: On the issue of micro-economic reform generally, including waterfront reform, I repeat what we have had cause to say on a number of occasions. If the Opposition talks about the condition of the Australian micro-economy and the condition with which we had to deal when we came to office, it will not be able to avoid one point: we have had to deal with a situation which was established by 30 years of Liberal-National Party governance out of the previous 34 years. I again put to the shadow Treasurer and the Leader of the Opposition that challenge that they have now had time to accept and about which they have had plenty of time to think: let them just tell us and the Australian community any period at all during those 30 years when they came within a bull's roar of a program of micro-economic reform to compare with what the Government has done generally in the area of micro-economic reform and in regard to the waterfront in particular.

When in government the Opposition parties did nothing but exacerbate the situation with respect to the waterfront. Under the program of micro-economic reform that we have brought through, there will be reform on the waterfront. There is a distinction between the way in which the Opposition would approach that reform and the way in which the Government would approach it. The Opposition can either give effect to its rhetoric and say that it will bring in draconian legislation that will punish employers and the trade unions if they do not do something, it can talk about it and produce chaos, or it can engage in the process of constructive consultation with the employers and the trade unions which will produce reform. Those are the alternatives. The Opposition did nothing. There is no reason to assume that in government it would have the courage to take on the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Try us.

—The Opposition has had the opportunity over the last few months in one area of micro-economic reform, that is, the aviation industry. What was it prepared to do there? What was its answer? It was to cave in to the pilots. When the pilots said they wanted a 30 per cent wage increase, the Opposition was prepared to say, `Yes, of course, have your 30 per cent wage increase'. It would have destroyed the Australian economy. That is what the Opposition's reform would have been. As a result of what is happening here, the pilots' component of the airline industry will have a 50 per cent productivity increase over what there was before. The Opposition had that chance and all it did was to say, `Give in'. That would have destroyed not only the aviation industry but also the Australian economy. As I have said before, the Opposition did not have the guts to begin to face up to the pilots; how would it get on with the wharfies?

—I refer the Treasurer to the Government's Budget decision to amalgamate the Industries Assistance Commission, the Inter-State Commission (ISC) and the Business Regulation Review Unit in a new Industry Commission. What progress has been made in implementing this decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the questioner indicates, in the Budget the Government said it would amalgamate a number of organisations that have compatible roles in furthering the process of structural reform. In particular, the Government is convinced of the need to join the Inter-State Commission and the Industries Assistance Commission because transport issues are such an integral aspect of business activity and are best considered in a broad economic context. I am aware of media commentary, though, claiming there is a constitutional impediment to what the Government is proposing. However, the Government's legal advice is that it is up to the Parliament to determine whether or not the Inter-State Commission comes into existence.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me just give some of the history. What the Government is now proposing is consistent with the history of the ISC provision in the Constitution. Since 1901 the ISC has been active only from 1913 to 1920 and from 1984 to now. The ISC Act was repealed in 1950. A new Act was not passed by Parliament until 1973 and this was not proclaimed until 1983. The bottom line is that, under our proposals, the role of the Inter-State Commission will be enhanced, not diminished, by being incorporated in a larger body with greater economic expertise under a dynamic new chairman, Mr Tony Cole. The Government regards it as vital to the process of accelerating micro-economic reform that the Industry Commission Bill be passed by the Parliament.

I add that, once again, the Opposition is standing in the way of the sort of micro-economic reform that it is saying that it supports. The Opposition has decided to oppose this Bill. As reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday, the National Party-the old Country Party-has rolled the shadow Treasurer, and, consequently, the Opposition has decided to oppose this vital Bill. So the Opposition has decided to oppose the Bill that will reform the inquiry and recommendation process on economy-wide industry reform. The Opposition talks about micro reform but, as usual, when it comes down to it, it is the old National Party tail wagging the coalition dog.

I remind the House of an instance of the shadow Treasurer relying on his experience as an adviser in the days of the former coalition Government in a quote in the Australian Financial Review on 6 July 1987. He said:

It was very frustrating. Howard would get rolled. Cabinet Ministers would sway the debate on the basis of an anecdote in the non-members' bar the night before, even if we had four feet of paper on the table . . . The farmers could produce anecdotes out of the air. I used to wonder a lot how much many of them understood.

For decades, members of the Country Party were responsible for corrupting markets in this country as successive Liberal Treasurers failed to stand up to them. The shadow Treasurer showed last week that it is par for the course for the Liberal Party. He is following in the footsteps of his former employer, the honourable member for Bennelong, who was famous for his weakness inside coalition Cabinets in not being able to get his way in the face of the Country Party. What we find in the Sydney Morning Herald is this:

. . . the push to dump the legislation came from the National Party transport spokesman, John Sharp, who had convinced his leader, Charles Blunt, to take on the Opposition spokesman on the Treasury, John Hewson. Hewson got done, despite support from the Opposition spokesman on finance, John Stone.
Of course, with him on one's side, no wonder! The article continues:
However, as the meeting progressed, it became clear he had used all his political capital getting his preferred position on the new rules for company tax . . .
I remind the House that they were more lenient arrangements, so he used up his capital agreeing to more lenient arrangements. The quotation concludes:
. . . with Sharp adamant, he was forced to capitulate.

This is the great lion who is going to change the face of the Australian economy. This is the person who is going to reform the wharves and ports-make all the micro changes. He is afraid to ask me the questions about the subject because he never likes the answers. The Leader of the Opposition will not put a question to me because, when he was shadow Treasurer, he used to die when he got the answers. As shadow Treasurer he used to have to ask a question once a month to at least let his crowd know that he still had some gumption, but now he will not ask at all. Here is the shadow Treasurer, who has been rolled by whom?-John Sharp from the National Party. He has convinced the Leader of the National Party-that great intellectual guru-that they should roll a Bill which establishes the Industry Commission with the Inter-State Commission as the major inquiry and recommending body in micro reform.

As the Prime Minister said, whenever the tests have come to the Opposition, whether it be micro reform with pilots and the airline industry, pharmaceuticals, or micro reform in the tax system, the Opposition has always opposed the lot. The Opposition left us with the port and wharf structure they referred to earlier-as the Prime Minister said-for 30 to 40 years of craven weakness in the face of the stevedoring companies and unions. This Government has produced a 40 per cent lift in wharf productivity and Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development crew-manning levels on coastal shipping, and the Opposition is still carping at it.

I will make the point clear: This notion that we can shift the public savings balance by 8 percentage points of gross domestic product and that we can shift macro-economic policy by 8 percentage points of GDP in the face of an underlying current account weakness of 6 per cent and that does not matter, but further reform of ports and wharves will make all the difference-that is just bunkum. That is small beer. That is what I pointed to. It is relatively small beer compared with macro policy. Even small as it is, the Opposition could not fix it up. Now the vehicle that the Government is employing to inquire into and make recommendations the Opposition does not even have the wit or the courage to carry though its own shadow Cabinet and party room.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Flinders!

—Here is another Liberal shadow Treasurer, like the former Liberal Treasurer, being run by the oafs of the Country Party, who gave Australia managed exchange rates, ripped away the income of Australian farmers for decades with an over-valued dollar, ripped away at farm profits with massive protection, and ingratiated themselves with Australian industry at the cost of Australia's industrial structure, and yet we still have this weak, cowardly, useless National Party running the Liberal Party in opposition. One can imagine what the result would be like in government.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister and I am sure that he will have noted the events that have occurred in eastern Europe throughout 1989, in particular in the last couple of weeks. I ask: What is the Government's reaction to current events in Czechoslovakia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Isaacs for his question. The Government shares-and I am sure the Opposition does-the hopes and aspirations of the Czechoslovak people and of the Czechoslovakian community here in Australia which have been engendered by the quite remarkable events of the past few days in Prague, Bratislava and other centres. The extinguishing of the Czech Spring, the Prague Spring in particular, by the Soviet-led invasion in August 1968 led, as we know, to 21 years of national anguish, frustration and stagnation. During that awful period of 21 years, decent Czechoslovaks, such as the great athlete Emil Zatopek, were subjected to harassment and humiliation. Their choice was simply either to suffer in silence or, as many of the country's outstanding talents did in that period, like the great film director Milos Forman, to seek freedom abroad.

ANSWER.PARA: Obviously we have a sense of exhilaration, which I am sure is shared throughout the House, at the spirit that is sweeping the Czechoslovak nation. The distinguished playwright Vaclar Haval, for so many years the victim of repression in his own country, is exercising an important influence on national affairs. It is particularly moving for all of us to see Alexander Dubcek, whose brutal overthrow in 1968-69 was followed by 20 years in isolation and humiliation, once again playing an important national role in his own country. On behalf of the Government I have sent Mr Dubcek a message expressing our admiration for his courage and constancy of purpose and welcoming his re-emergence on Czechoslovakia's national stage.

The corollary of these developments is the overthrow of the quislings, the opportunists and the conformists who have prospered since 1968. In this place last Tuesday I said that their days were numbered. Milos Jakes, the hard line party leader who presided over the major purge after 1969, has fallen, along with other leading Brezhnevite figures. Clearly, a major shake-out is in progress and, equally clearly, that shake-out is not yet complete. On behalf of the Government I express the hope that representative institutions and personalities, consonant with the strong national tradition of democracy in Czechoslovakia, will emerge and that they will be able to tackle the major tasks of reform which have accumulated over the decades. This development will serve to reinforce the currently strongly positive trend in East-West relations and also facilitate closer bilateral relations between Australia and Czechoslovakia.

I conclude by saying that our Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, hopes to call into Prague during his proposed visit to eastern Europe next month, and I hope that he will have contact there with this new, emerging, exciting political leadership.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate that the Leader of the Opposition should look very closely at the decision that was handed down at the end of last week by the judge of the Supreme Court. I will come to the specifics of the question in a moment. There is only one part of the decision by the judge of the Supreme Court which I presume the Leader of the Opposition will not question in its analysis. There is only one matter out of which the Government basically draws any pleasure or comfort and it is this: the judge of the Supreme Court had the responsibility, in that atmosphere as distinct from this, of analysing, in a detached and judicial way, the allegations made in this place, which were also made outside this place by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. The Leader of the Opposition has been at one with them in making allegations, in regard to the history of this issue, that there has been a conspiracy between the Government and the airlines of this country to bring about this confrontation. Day after day in this place he has given support to that proposition.

ANSWER.PARA: As distinct from the Opposition's allegations being thrown around in this place, in the calm and detached atmosphere of the Supreme Court the judge had the responsibility of analysing the allegations which were made before him by the Federation, the same allegations which the Opposition has been throwing around day after day. The judge's finding in regard to this matter was clear. He repudiated unequivocally those allegations. He said that there was no evidence to sustain the proposition and he rejected the argument that there had been any conspiracy between the Government and the airlines to bring about a confrontation. Specifically, he found that it was the AFAP which, to use his words, had been spoiling for a fight.

I ask honourable members to understand the implications of the judgment for the Opposition, because in one statement the judge of the Supreme Court has totally destroyed the position which the Opposition has adopted in this place. It is further evidence of the remarkable hypocrisy of the Leader of the Opposition and the total Opposition in this place that now there has been an untrammelled opportunity to test the allegations which the Opposition has thrown around so recklessly and without any basis, the judge of the Supreme Court has found its allegations and those of its colleagues, the AFAP, to be entirely without foundation. I come from that basic point to the deep regret that we on this side of the House have that it was necessary for this to happen, because from day one we pleaded with the AFAP to operate within the processes of the Industrial Relations Commission. We pleaded with it to stay within that system.

TALK.START.PARA: —So much for compromise.
—Order! The honourable member for Casey will cease interjecting.
—Having pleaded with the AFAP--
—Order! If honourable members on my left continue interjecting I will name them.

—We had pleaded with the AFAP, as had the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), to stay within the system which has provided for, is abided by and is used by the whole of the trade union movement in this country-that is, if it had claims for increases it should go to the Industrial Relations Commission and argue them. It was pointed out to the AFAP by the Government and the ACTU that if it did not follow those processes but said: `No, we don't want to use that area where there is the protection for those who take industrial action and who process their claim. We want to take ourselves outside that system, with all the protection that it provides'-no-one forced it to do so-it must understand and expect that it would be subjected to civil processes which could be extremely damaging for it.

ANSWER.PARA: We did not want that to happen. We pleaded that the airline pilots should stay within the system and not expose themselves to that risk. Time after time we said, `Stay within the system'. We said, `If as a result of your decision to go outside the system the airlines decide that it is necessary, in the context of your creation, to take action they will have our support'. That action having been taken, I repeat what I have said. We take no joy or comfort from it. We did not want it to happen. We pleaded with it that it should not happen. That having happened, the Opposition has to live with the fact that a judge of the Supreme Court has dealt with the allegations that the Opposition had made. Day after day in this place and outside it the Opposition has joined with the Federation of Air Pilots in condemning this Government and the airlines, saying that we are in cahoots and that we are in conspiracy. What the Opposition has to live with is the fact that a judge of the Supreme Court has repudiated that, found it to be without substance and that in fact it is the Federation which has been spoiling for a fight.

Let me conclude by repeating what I have said before: the Industrial Relations Commission has said that there is a way for the Federation of Air Pilots to become involved in the reconstruction of the airline industry. The Supreme Court judge has spoken in regard to these allegations, and he has dismissed them, as they should have been. The Industrial Relations Commission, in an atmosphere distinct from that of this place, is saying what can happen, what is the way for the Federation of Air Pilots to be involved in the reconstruction of the airline industry. It made it quite clear, and let me take this opportunity of indicating what that process is. The Industrial Relations Commission has said that the Australian Federation of Air Pilots should accept three conditions. They are not conditions that are imposed specifically upon the Australian Federation of Air Pilots; they apply to all unions. The first is that the Federation should lift the embargo upon its members seeking employment; secondly, that it should accept the decision of the Industrial Relations Commission; and, thirdly, that it should be bound by the national wage case principles.

The Industrial Relations Commission has said that if the Federation accepts those three conditions, which apply to everyone else, it can apply to be bound by the award which is now based upon the contract. Further, following those points, if the Federation then seeks to be so bound and says, as it does, that it does not like the conditions of the contract, in those circumstances it is open for it to argue before the Commission for a variation of the conditions of that award. In other words, the Industrial Relations Commission has set down the path quite clearly as to how the Australian Federation of Air Pilots can be involved in the reconstruction of the industry.

It is both my hope and the Government's hope that the Australian Federation of Air Pilots will accept that path which has been so clearly outlined by the Commission. That is the one and only way in which the Australian Federation of Air Pilots can now, in this situation in which the airline industry is being rebuilt, have a part in it. If the Australian Federation of Air Pilots makes that decision to follow the path laid down by the Industrial Relations Commission and seeks to be bound by the award, this Government will not be heard to oppose it.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Peacock) proposed:
That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving forthwith:

That this House censures the Prime Minister for his arrogant disregard for the impact of his Government's mismanagement of Australian families and businesses struggling under record high interest rates and struggling to cope with the continuing fall-out from the pilots' dispute.
Mr Beazley-We will accept the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Prime Minister for his arrogant disregard for the impact of his Government's mismanagement of Australian families and businesses struggling under record high interest rates and struggling to cope with the continuing fall-out from the pilots' dispute.

We move this motion of censure of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) with very good cause, and it follows the censure of him by so many people in South Australia last Saturday. There may once have been a time when this Prime Minister was governing, albeit that that is debatable. What is not debatable, but is an irrefutable fact, is that this Prime Minister-one only had to hear him at Question Time to confirm this bluntly and to the point-is a spent force whose time is up and who is a positive impediment to effective and compassionate government. This is a government without direction. It has lost its way. It gives no relief, makes no progress, has no credibility. It is a policy-bankrupt government.

I want briefly to remind the House what I said last week of the five steps of the paralysis of policy of this Government. Those five steps were that, instead of policies, we have the politics of the big lie, the politics of the quick fix, the politics of personal abuse, the politics of hypocrisy and the politics of confusion. The politics of the big lie are substantiated by reminding people of the statements the Prime Minister has made. Interestingly, I forgot one last week. The first was that no child will live in poverty by 1990. The second was that interest rates will fall. The third was that the pilots dispute is over. The one I forgot last week was that their will be no capital gains tax. That is the politics of the big lie. It is followed, as I have said, by the politics of the quick fix. We have Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd, Coronation Hill and the bank interest subsidy. There is the politics of personal abuse-Elliott, Parbo, the pilots federation and the pensioners. What about pensioner Bell? As we have said, any man who calls an age pensioner a silly old bugger does not deserve to be Prime Minister.

We also have the politics of hypocrisy. There are the rorts of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the travel allowance. I forgot the matter of Keating's rorts last week. There was the travel allowance, the tax return and the travel documents. I forgot the travel documents. I assume the Treasurer got to Tokyo this time with a visa. They would have given him a visitor's visa pretty rapidly because they would not have wanted him to establish a case for permanent residence. There was then the exclusion of the trade unions from capital gains tax, and the elaboration of the policy of confusion.

In contrast to this policy-bankrupt Government, the Opposition has given the nation the Economic Action Plan-substantiated throughout, a document which is the most detailed and comprehensive tax and expenditure program ever presented by an Opposition party. It is an action plan for a more productive and fairer Australia. By the end of our first term in government the tax rates will be cut, interest rates will be lower, government will be smaller, inflation will be reduced, productivity and real wages will be higher and the growth in foreign debt will be brought under control.

At Question Time I heard either the Prime Minister or the Treasurer talking about the inadequacy of the proposals we have, for example, on fiscal policy. Let me remind the House that our fiscal policy will reduce outlays by $2.7 billion to 22.5 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP), the lowest since 1964-65. We will reduce the tax revenue as a proportion of GDP to 24.3 per cent, the lowest level in six years. We will direct $1.6 billion from the first year of the privatisation program towards reducing public debt, and we will increase the Budget surplus, including asset sales, by $1.7 billion to $10.8 billion-which, at 3 per cent of GDP, is the largest increase since comparable figures have been kept.

Time and again we have asked for the Government's policies. It does not matter in what field of government administration we raise the point about the Government policies for the future, the Government cannot tell us what it will do. It has not produced a blueprint or a schedule. More than 30 policy documents have been produced by the Opposition; not one has been produced by the Government. No wonder the National Farmers Federation berated the Prime Minister last week and said that the only policy discussion around today concerns Opposition policy. The Government has no policy.

The test is simple. We can go around to Government Ministers and ask, `Can we have a copy of your policy for the future?'. They say, `We don't have one'. We can pose various questions. Time and again we have posed them. Where is the Prime Minister's policy for relief for families? He does not have one. Will he commit himself to the discipline of forgoing the proceeds of bracket creep? No. Does he intend to reduce the size of the public sector? No. Where is his program for privatisation-the small beer of micro-economic reform? None exists. Will he adopt our spending cuts? No way. Will he liberalise the labour market? He cannot even work out which way to go about it. Hawke and Keating have different approaches. Where is the Prime Minister's policy on injecting foreign competition into coastal shipping? He has no idea. He simply dumps on previous governments. We might as well go back to Federation. The fact is that he does not have any policies for the future. He has a very simple tactic of just stating the problem, either dismissing it or claiming victory, and then leaving the field. So nothing at all is done. When we are elected, as we will be at the next election, once again the Australian people will have a government that has a passion for results rather than a government that has a passion simply for the future.

The substance of this censure motion relates to both interests rates and of course the pilots dispute. They sum things up about this Government. Let us go over a little bit a minor part of the Government's history on interest rates. The Prime Minister, in his policy speech during the last election, pledged that he would get interest rates down. He said this as late as this year simply because he was campaigning in the Western Australian elections; not because he knew anything would happen. He said, `Interest rates will fall by the end of the year'. After months and months of buffeting, because people are hurting so much, he said over the weekend, `I could just say, ``All right, down come interest rates'' '. There is then the more revealing statement for this Government which allegedly relies on a quasi-independent Reserve Bank of Australia. The most ludicrous, damning and most pointed statement of all was, `I could just ring up and say, ``Ease the screws: rates down'' '.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister said that?
—The Prime Minister said that on Saturday. What a statement; what an indictment; what a reflection on the so-called independence of the Reserve Bank!

SPEECH.PARA: What about the pilots? This really is lovely stuff. Everyone is suffering; everyone is inconvenienced. The effect on the trade balance is well known. But this man, who is in another world, has his head in the sky-but the planes are not there with him, only the interest rates. He has no idea of how to fix the problem, yet he stood up here today and said, `I pleaded with them'. Government members know what he said and the Australian people know what he said: he declared war on the pilots. He could have these planes back in the sky tomorrow. He, with his Government, is the owner of Australian Airlines Ltd. He could test the pilots. Instead of testing them with his phoney language, he could take them to the court and direct Australian Airlines-it is his airline-to sit down and negotiate with the pilots. If he were to test them out he would have them back in the air straight away. He should stop the compensation, test the pilots out and negotiate with them. But oh no. Honourable members know what is going on. They know who gets on the phone and says, `I want the compensation'. So the compensation is paid-taxpayers' money; money paid by everyone here-just to keep this dispute going because the Prime Minister declared war. The Prime Minister was the one who said, on 20 August, that the common law proceedings brought by the airlines had `the full support of my Government'.

Anyone who has any doubts about the ineffectiveness of this Government and the havoc it is wreaking on the Australian people should just remember the other sorts of phrases that have been used to justify the inept behaviour of this Prime Minister. He said, `The pilots dispute is over'. But the best of all-and the real test of this man-is that he said that if he could not protect Australia against the pilots, `I would not deserve to be Prime Minister'. More than 100 days have gone by and he has not protected Australia-and he does not deserve to be Prime Minister. The people of South Australia showed him that. They showed him what they thought.

The only comparable occasion in recent history was the narrow return of the Dunstan Government in 1975 when, like Mr Bannon, Mr Dunstan pleaded with the South Australian people to disregard Federal issues. He said, `Please get them out of the way. Don't take any notice of what the Whitlam Government is doing; judge me'. Dunstan squeaked back. Do honourable members known when Dunstan squeaked back? It was only weeks before the greatest devastation wreaked on the Australian Labor Party in the history of this nation. That was in 1975.

The only justifiable reason for this Prime Minister's not anticipating what happened in South Australia was the fact that he was hardly there. Anyone who blinked would have missed him because Mr Bannon did not want him there. Mr Bannon would not have a bar of the Prime Minister's participating in that election campaign. If Premier Bannon were here today he would probably have seconded this motion. No wonder the Prime Minister does not know the consequences of the South Australian election results, because Mr Bannon and his Party would not let him visit the State. The Prime Minister went there to handle the submarine project, which was understandable, because it was appropriate that he should stand on the conning tower during the election campaign. It was also appropriate for Mr Bannon. If one looks at the history of the Bannon Government, one will discover that it has torpedoed just about every other major development in the State. The majority of South Australians were aware of the situation, but the Prime Minister was not, because the Bannon Government would not let him go there. The Prime Minister is a liability to the Labor Party but, tragically, he is an even greater liability to this nation. The sooner he ceases the rhetoric of saying, `I can fix this and I can fix that', squirming his way through Question Time and deceiving-and that is what he is doing today-his own Party--
Mr Hawke interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we go again. Honourable members probably cannot hear these little remarks behind the table. In fact, he does not want anybody to hear them. If I were him, I would keep it up. I think that it says more about the Prime Minister than it does about me. If it is so worth while, tell this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hawke interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what the Prime Minister was saying. Some people can forgive mistakes of judgment, but they cannot forgive the deliberate and calculated deception practised by this Prime Minister. He is the leader of a party in government. We and the Australian people expect some guidance from him but, more particularly, we expect some leadership. Over the past 12 months this Parliament and nation have witnessed his continued and unashamed attempts to mislead the Australian people. How can the Prime Minister say the sorts of things he does and then, two months later, seek to wriggle out of them? Does the Prime Minister make up the statements as he goes? He certainly has no central purpose to his Government. If he did have some central purpose, he would not continue with these economic policies which are retarding the development of the nation-even worse, they are retarding the lives of so many people.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the pilots dispute, the Prime Minister just does not care. The Prime Minister is content to just wriggle through any matter. The pity of it is that the pain being inflicted on Australians is simply not necessary. If he undertook the micro-economic reform that he knows is required, our trading position would improve and interest rates would decrease. However, he has put micro-economic reform into the too hard basket. The harsh reality is that this Government is absolutely paralysed in terms of policy. All it does is set up studies and, when it runs out of agencies to research the problems, it simply sets up more government bodies to undertake more studies. We have seen this pattern in the establishment of the Industry Commission. Did honourable members hear the remarks made by the Treasurer this afternoon when he referred to `this significant micro-economic reform' that he has introduced? I refer to the amalgamation of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) and the Inter-State Commission. This Government, after the previous election, said that the hallmark and the pinnacle of this third term of the Hawke Government was to be micro-economic reform. The one thing that it did in this Budget was to amalgamate the IAC and the Inter-State Commission. They will all do the same thing: they are included in the one Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are opposing it.

—We are opposing it, you fool, because under the Constitution the Inter-State Commission has an ongoing provision. However, the Government is seeking to amend it in a non-constitutional way. It seems to me that the Government's legal advice is about as good as the medical advice it propagates around here, for which it churns out fees on the old Medicare! In short, the problem for the Australian people today is that the Prime Minister and his Government are paralysed. The Government is stagnating. It has no ideas and no direction. I concede that two weeks ago the single, most important initiative was taken by the Government: the Prime Minister wrote to his Ministers asking for some ideas. I hope that Opposition members keep those cards and letters coming in because nothing is coming from the Government side. It was the most important initiative taken to date, yet we have seen nothing and we will not see anything.

SPEECH.PARA: The only alternative lies with the coalition. The Government cannot produce the detailed reforms so carefully worked through and fully costed as appears in our Economic Action Plan. As I said at the outset, I could go to every Minister's office in the building and ask for the policies for the future, but I would not get any because those policies simply have not been determined. The Government is running down the nation without any charter whatsoever for the future. The Government knows that a single reliance on high interest rates is not the only way to go. The Government cannot bring itself to spell out, as we have in our document, a coordinated economic program on fiscal, wages and monetary policy, the structural reforms, the micro-economic reforms, the privatisation program and the tax changes. Our plan offers the future for Australia.

The policy processes in the Hawke Government, however, have become nothing but a farce-Ministers publicly campaign against Ministers; major public policy statements are made without consultation, whether the Treasurer on the run in Tokyo on enterprise unions or the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) on family policy; and key policy areas are given over to special interest lobbies. Last week, the Government said that we cannot have its tax policy until Bill Kelty comes back from his Christmas holidays; it has been deferred till next year. Last week, the Prime Minister sought to deny that the extreme environmentalists were being given veto powers over mining projects, which they are. Honourable members will remember that the penultimate point the Prime Minister made in his speech then was to say that it was outrageous that I had made an allegation that the Government had sold out to environmentalists.

If we test what is happening in the area of value-added industries and see the requests and needs for development in this country, we will see them retarded if the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) can get to the door first. Honourable members do not have to take my word for it. They can take that of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) because he pointed out that the Government has no policy for sustained development; in the pursuit of votes it has sold out to the green movement; it has no sensible, sensitive, balanced environmental policy, as we do. The reality is that the Government has a desperate need to give a lead, to give relief; it just cannot do it. As a consequence, I am not surprised that headlines such as `Hawke is a liability say MPs' appear in papers. The problem is that the Prime Minister is a liability not just to the Australian Labor Party; tragically, he is now a liability also to the Australian nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to respond to the observations of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). I commence by taking the latter part of his remarks, in which he made the amazing allegation that under this Government there are no policies or strategies for the future.
—Tell us some.

—If the honourable member for O'Connor will just contain himself, I will do precisely that. I trust that members opposite will not question the source to which I go, because it is Access Economics. I think that the Opposition will accept Access Economics checking us, because it is the organisation to which it resorted and which was responsible for checking the Opposition. The Leader of the Opposition said that in this country we have no policies which enable sustainable development. Let us have Access Economics check us. In its publication, which came out on 6 October 1989, just two or three weeks ago, under `Investment Monitor', it says that it has provided this unique listing, sector by sector, of some 500 investment projects, worth over $5m each, under construction, committed or under consideration, in mining, manufacturing, tourism and public sector investment related to foreign exchange earnings. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Projects listed have a total value of over $90 billion.
As a proportion of total investment tourism represents 34 per cent, manufacturing 30.5 per cent, the public sector 21 per cent and mining 14.5 per cent.
Of total investment 54 per cent is under construction or committed and 46 per cent is under consideration.
Access Economics goes on to say:
. . . the list is not padded out with a large number of projects which are unlikely to proceed on commercial grounds.
We have included projects in mining, manufacturing and tourism as major sectors with the potential to earn foreign exchange.
Projects are spread across a much wider range of industries than was the case with the resources boom.

This is the report on this Government by Access Economics. It is remarkable, in the light of the statement by the Leader of the Opposition that this Government has no policies for the future for sustainable development. What are the projected foreign income earnings of these projects listed by Access Economics? Of those which are already under construction and committed, the estimate is of some $5 billion per annum of foreign exchange earnings and, of the total $90 billion, an estimate of some $10 billion.

We have heard all this noise. Today we have witnessed the remarkable spectacle of the recycled leader with his recycled speech, but in this recycled speech of the recycled leader, we have it failing on every point, as I will show. At the last point of this recycled speech of the recycled leader he said that the Government has no policies for sustain- able development. A report on the Government by his own examiners, Access Economics, destroys the Opposition's own proposition: $90 billion worth of sustainable investment development. The Leader of the Opposition has been destroyed out of the mouth of his own mob. That is how much notice we can take of him.

I now go to the most remarkable comment I think we have heard in this Parliament from the recycled leader. Quite remarkably, he made the observation that he was concerned with the return of an effective and compassionate government. I do not want to engage in a whole lot of rhetoric. I will sustain my proposition that that is the most cynical piece of hypocrisy that I have heard in this Parliament by just testing the Opposition's record against that of the Government. That can be done by looking at some very significant groups; that will test the compassion of the Liberals and the Nationals against that of the Government. Let us look at what has happened. Do not let us talk about compassion in this rhetorical sense, let us do a simple test. What happened to groups of people who needed the compassion of government under the Liberals and Nationals when they were in government and what has happened to those same groups who needed compassion under this Government? I take these examples. I take the case of a sole parent with two children. I guess people would say that that group in our society-sole parents with the responsibility of looking after two children-is a pretty classic test by which to judge the compassion of alternative governments. What happened to that group in the period 1975 to 1983? What happened to their real disposable income in the seven years under this crowd opposite? The real disposable income of a sole parent with two children went down by 4 per cent. In seven years, the compassion that those sole parents experienced was a reduction in their real disposable income. What has happened under this Government between 1983 and 1989?

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing!
—Nothing, he says. I will tell you the answer, you fool. Under this Government there has been an increase in real disposable income of 15 per cent.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order.
—And they talk about compassion!
—Order! The Prime Minister might withdraw the remark that he made about the honourable member for Casey.
—Yes, he is not a fool.
—Order! The Prime Minister might withdraw the remark.

—I withdraw the statement that he is a fool. I merely say that he cannot understand statistics. I say that he says it is compassionate to reduce the real disposable income of a sole parent and two children by 4 per cent and that to increase it by 15 per cent under us is not compassionate. I do not say he is a fool; I simply say he cannot understand the facts.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at another group in respect of whom one might make the judgment about compassion. Let us look at the position of a married pensioner couple with two children. Would one think that a married pensioner couple with two children belong to the sort of group by which one might test the compassion of government? What happened in the seven-year period in government of that mob-these people who now propose compassion? The real disposable income of a married pensioner couple with two children was slashed by 2 per cent in their period of government, whilst under us it has increased by 14 per cent. There is the test of compassion. The Opposition can have all its rhetoric about Australian families and compassion; it slashed the real disposable income of that group as well and we have massively increased it.

Let us take the case of the long-term unemployed single adult, and let us take two categories-one who is not renting privately and the other who is renting privately. What did the Opposition do for the long-term adult unemployed? It slashed the real disposable income of that person by 19 per cent. This is a person who, through no fault of his own, was unemployed for a long period and the Opposition in government-and the Leader of the Opposition has the hypocrisy to get up in this place and talk about compassion-slashed the real disposable income of that person by 19 per cent. Under this Government, if he or she is not renting privately there has been a 23 per cent increase in real disposable income, or if he or she is renting privately, 32 per cent.

We can have all the rhetoric in the world about compassion, but these people, who are now proposing the same economic policies that they had before and who now talk about compassion, can be tested in each one of the categories of our society who look properly to government for compassion. The Opposition when in government slashed their income in real terms. Through carefully targeted and responsible government, this Government has significantly increased the real disposable income of those groups who must and can look only to government for compassion. The rhetoric about compassion must be tested against the record.

Against that factual situation, we now have to judge what it is that these people would offer against what this Government has done. I have disposed of the absolute untruths of the Leader of the Opposition in his statement about no sustainable development. I have disposed of that by reference to his own Access Economics. I have disposed of his hypocrisy about compassion, but let me go to that part of the Leader of the Opposition's speech about the grand plan the Opposition has for the future-the Economic Action Plan. The other day I had cause to refer briefly to an analysis by Mr Gittins, just to get some idea of how much substance can be given to this so-called Economic Action Plan. Everyone heard what it was going to do: zero inflation, minimum interest rates, rising employment, everything one could dream of. Let us share just a few thoughts with Mr Gittins about how much significance can be attached to this. He said:
I've just got hold of my copy-

this is the Economic Action Plan that has been advanced in this censure motion as the answer. This is what they did before-smashed the economy and brought the worst recession in 50 years, and at the same time there was double-digit unemployment and double-digit inflation. That is what they did, but now they have the new Economic Action Plan, which will do it differently. Gittins goes on to say:
This was where Dr Hewson revealed his great insight, the revelation that will make him the world's greatest Treasurer. This discovery, termed the `integrated economic strategy'-
which the Leader of the Opposition has been talking about-
will, he says, constitute a `different world' to the one we have known. Clearly, it will confound the conventional wisdom as to how economies are managed.
The Hewson breakthrough is simply stated. His strategy will have as its central objective the control of inflation.
That is what the Leader of the Opposition said. Gittins continued:

Inflation and wage growth will be down to the level of our trading partners by the end of the first term. But this will be achieved with less, rather than greater, reliance on monetary policy and won't involve a rise in unemployment.
What did Gittins say about this strategy? He said:
See what I mean? It's path-breaking stuff; Nobel Prize material.
But let me make my shamefaced confession upfront. I'm having difficulty following the logic of the different world.
Boy oh boy! Not only is Mr Gittins having difficulty following the logic of this nonsense; so is every commentator who has looked at it.

TALK.START.PARA: —But not Andrew.

—No; do not be unkind to Andrew. Perhaps Andrew does understand it. If he does, why will he not expose himself to the press to explain it all? Because, like Mr Gittins, he knows that it is a load of hogwash. Mr Gittins, having given it the consolidated raspberry, said:

SPEECH.PARA: If you get down to it, what's the core of this pathbreaking stuff, this Nobel Prize winning new economic theory? The core of it is wages policy. It is clear to me that wages policy lies at the heart of the breakthrough to a different world.

Let me conclude by examining, in terms of what the Leader of the Opposition has said, how much credence can be given to the central core of this new world wages policy. I will do it by relating it to the airline pilots dispute. We had the most massive wages breakout and every first year economics student knew the inevitable result. That is what the Opposition is saying now and what happened then? We had the worst recession in 50 years because the whole economy collapsed and that is what the Opposition would have done today. The new home buyer has seen the average house move elusively away from him, as his income has been restrained and as house prices and interest rates have skyrocketed in what was a speculative boom created by the Government's economic mismanagement. Following the introduction of the capital gains tax the only place in which many families could put their money was their home. We have seen record increases in house prices and interest rates in recent times. More recently, as interest rates have started to bite in the housing sector-that is the only area where we see any evidence of them biting-house prices have started to fall. Looking at the simple equation of the average two- income family earning around $45,000 to $46,000 and needing $64,100 to buy a home, one sees that there are only two ways in which such people will be able to get there-that is, a substantial boost in their income or a substantial fall in house prices to make that equation add up. When we consider how much the median house price has already fallen in Sydney, we must remember that typically in the past house prices did not fall very much. They tended to stop rising for a time, flattening out a bit, but they did not fall very much. Honourable members have seen the advertisements in real estate offices where a little old man with a walking stick is described as the person who waited for house prices to fall. The other part of our motion relates to the pilots dispute. We have seen a conscious attempt on the part of the Government to downplay the significance of the pilots dispute. It has ranged from the Treasurer saying that when he was in a leading Sydney hotel it still had a high occupancy rate right through to the Prime Minister denying that the dispute continues to exist. The people of Australia know that the dispute exists. They know the damage that it is doing to the tourist industry and to a large part of the small business industry in this country and they have one simple question: Why has the Government not solved it?

The Government is in a unique position in this dispute. It is an employer in this dispute. Effectively, it owns Australian Airlines and it could instruct the management of Australian Airlines to start negotiating immediately. The Government could end this dispute in a few days by providing the right sort of lead, by recognising that it is an employer in this dispute. I believe that the Government could get a commitment from the pilots to return to work in return for those negotiations being initiated. I believe that it could get those negotiations based on productivity and that it could, as a result, significantly start to change the face of industrial relations in this country. In recent days the Treasurer has become very attracted to our idea of enterprise bargaining. There is probably an opportunity in settling this dispute even for him to initiate the process of enterprise bargaining. Maybe we could have an Australian Airlines enterprise union negotiating this dispute. There are endless possibilities. The point is that this dispute can be settled in a matter of a few days. That settlement procedure can start the process of tying wages directly with productivity, which is precisely what this country needs, and that negotiating process can see the pilots return to work in return for those negotiations.

Even more than that, the Government can actually take the economic agenda one step further forward in solving this dispute by going into the area of competition. In an interview in the Australian this morning the Treasurer started to burn up his history of inactivity in micro-reform. We are told that micro-reform is no longer important, that macro-policy is king, always was king and always will be king. He is getting out of the micro-reform area. Yet in the settlement of this pilots dispute the Government could actually make a substantial change to the nature of competition in the airline industry and those negotiations that I have been talking about could take place in the context of a genuinely more deregulated and competitive airline market. Right now, foreign airlines are flying on domestic routes all over this country. Why does the Government not keep some of them there as a form of immediate competition in the nature of the settlement of this dispute and see those negotiations take place in a much more competitive market environment?

The Government's concept of airline deregulation and competition in the airline industry ought to be drawn out for the average Australian. At the end of next year we are hardly going to see anything out of this dispute-mickey mouse deregulation at best; no genuine new competition; no effective competition coming in; and probably one dominant Australian airline left, Ansett Airlines of Australia, the other one being sent to the wall by this debilitating dispute that is probably consciously part of the procedure that is going on in the back rooms of the Government at the present time. This is a ridiculous situation for the country to be left in.

My point is that the dispute settlement can actually make substantial progress in two ways. First, it can initiate the sorts of changes in the industrial relations area that this country dramatically needs-wage increases genuinely based on productivity. What this country needs is a genuine productivity break-out. Second, the Government can get genuine competition into the airline industry, one of the most important sectors of our transportation industry at the present time. Now is a golden opportunity to advance both labour market reform and competition policy or micro-economic reform in the settlement of this dispute. What do we get as a response from this Government? What is the answer that the Prime Minister has given to the people of Australia? He started out by declaring war and he backed out when it got a bit tough. He tried a whole lot of other devious devices in order to distract attention from the fact that the dispute has got out of hand, that he inflamed it at the beginning and that now, of course, the bottom line cost, as is so often the case, is going to be a substantial segment of the small business community in Australia.

The people of South Australia last weekend showed that they are aware of the damage the Government has done to home owners and home buyers. They are aware of the damage that the Government's policies have done to the small business community. They voted decisively against the Australian Labor Party. If the Government wants to test us in the national forum on the same sort of issues, we will fight the national election on interest rates, the Government's interest rate policy, and on solutions to the pilots dispute, because the Australian Labor Party and the Government stand totally condemned.

Yet the Government in 2 1/2 years has presided over a bigger micro-reform restructuring of the economy than at any time in the post war years. Let me record the progress in the micro-agenda in these last 2 1/2 years. There has been a cut in the company tax rate from 49 per cent to 39 per cent-the largest micro-change of all. There has been a massive cut of 33 per cent in industrial protection-the second only cut since the war, and both times by a Labor government. There has been reform to the textile, clothing and footwear industries and to agricultural markets. There has been total reform of superannuation savings and a total remaking of the savings picture, with an extension of the imputation system to superannuation funds. There has been total deregulation of the airlines system, including air freight. There have been reforms to government business enterprises. There has been a 40 per cent lift in waterfront productivity. Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development crew manning levels for Australian shipping have been introduced. There has been reform of grain handling. Finally, but importantly, there has been award restructuring, the first attempt ever by a government to change the nature of the Australian award structure. However, this time it will pop out with $130 billion of gross debt.

Then another Labor government will have to come in and clean it up again. How many times have we cleaned up after other governments?
