He believes that he can just traffic his way into office on a recital of half-truths and prejudices.

This Government has the tightest fiscal policy in the country's history. It has a workable wages policy delivering realistic and competitive wage outcomes and a monetary policy set firmly to play its proper role in moderating demand to lift product growth. We have the most comprehensive economic reform program in Australia's history. There has been structural reform of the variety I have just mentioned, tax reform, financial deregulation, airline deregulation, oil industry deregulation, ports and shipping restructuring, productivity-based wage rises, award restructuring, cuts to import tariffs and a better skilled work force. We have the highest investment share in our history, coming from corporate tax rates and imputation, and domestic savings are encouraged not only by a massive shift in the public savings balance by 8 per cent of GDP but also by a total change of occupational superannuation which, along with the Budget surplus, is totally changing the face of the Australian savings picture.

That is the work of a serious government. Only a serious government can change Australia and keep it changing and protect all Australians from being beaten to a pulp by the world markets. Imagine if the Leader of the Opposition were standing against the rest of the world trying to protect Australia from the ravages of the marketplace in the face of Liberal and National Party weakness. We would be ripped to pieces. The antics in the House of Representatives and the thespian tricks and all the rest would then count for nothing. I move:

But a believable promise-and the Government is going down this track-would be buying favours, buying support. The Treasurer came in here today and lectured us about his commitment, his guts, his preparedness to restructure this economy, and then he scurried out. Where was he when the Government had to take some really hard decisions? When it comes to the hard decisions, the Treasurer cannot cop it. We had an example with Coronation Hill-a well known gold mine with platinum and palladium. But what did the Treasurer say? Where was he? Was he in there fighting toe to toe, shoulder to shoulder with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy? No way. The Treasurer sold out, just like the Minister for Defence sold out, just like all of those opposite sold out, on the sort of decision that is necessary in the national interest. The man who came in here and lectured us, who pointed over here and said, `Why aren't you tough and hairy-chested just like me; why can't you take hard decisions', would not know a hard decision if it hit him in the head. When he had his chance he caved in to the Prime Minister. The craven pursuit of votes was more important to the Treasurer, the Prime Minister, the entire front bench and the entire back bench than a decision in the nation's interests. That is the standard of government we have right now-a government that has no answers because its absolute priority is expediency to try to get it off the political hook that it impaled itself on because of its own ineptitude. Those opposite would not know what to do.

Because the Treasurer is now back in the country with no hope of delivering on micro-economic reform because it is too hard, he tries to repaint the political debate. All of a sudden micro-economic reform is small beer-about a seven, if one measures it against the Treasurer's performance. And he probably could not even handle that. He says that macro-economic policy is king. I say this to him: he will not succeed in this country unless he can deliver on micro-economic reform. The key to us being competitive and successful is a genuinely restructured economy beginning with the labour market. What is the Government's industrial relations policy post-Thursday? What is its attitude to damages against unions as a result of their strikes? What is its industrial relations policy on that? Or has Mr Kelty not told them? Have we not had the meeting with the Australian Council of Trade Unions yet to have the policy parameters laid down for the Government? He has probably taken an early holiday. Simon Crean has left the country, so the Government does not have any briefing notes and does not know where to go or what to do. The Government really does have a problem because there is only so much money that it can throw around buying support.

We have seen nothing short of a basket- load of expedient decisions ranging from those involving Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd through to the airlines. Was that not a proud decision? It was a case of the Prime Minister again looking after the big end of town. Never mind the tourist industry. Support the airlines. The loss in foreign exchange earnings as a result of the downturn in the tourist industry is likely to be between $2 billion and $3 billion. While the Government is looking after Ansett's bottom line and ensuring that its profit and loss account is all right, while it is ensuring that the Australian Airlines accounts look all right and that East-West Airlines receives a subsidy, what is it doing about the tourist industry? What about the Queensland tourist industry and its bottom line? What are we going to do about future bankruptcies? What will we do about the children who will have their standard of living reduced? What will we do about the people who have invested their life savings? That is why this Government is on the nose in the electorate. While it is looking after the big blokes-the people who puff cigars with the Prime Minister, who come and stay with him, take him fishing and look after him-it is not looking after the little people of Australia, the people who vote.

No-one in this Government knows what the real priority should be. This Government has been reduced to the politics of `feel good', the phone call from the chief executive who says, `Prime Minister, what a great decision that was. We will support you, Prime Minister'. What about the workers? This is supposed to be a Labor Administration. What about the workers and their wives and their children?

TALK.START.PARA: —They wouldn't have a job under you.

—The reality is that those people will not vote for this Government. Honourable members opposite should look at the South Australian result: 20 per cent swings in the safest Labor seats. It is no wonder that this man, the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), doorknocks at weekends. He gets into the VIP aircraft and flies back to Perth, gets into his joggers and hightails it off to the suburbs, where he knocks on doors and says, `I am doing my best and I am fighting for you over there; it is that obnoxious man we call the Prime Minister'.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth is that confidence in this Government has been eroded. Business people do not have any confidence in this Government, nor does the community. Further, no backbenchers have any confidence in this Government because they do not believe that they will be re-elected. Government members do not believe that anything can be done to turn around the ship of state. The reality is that the Government is so divided, so faction-ridden, so compromised that there is no hope at all.

We have a brawl between Old Silver and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). We know what the Treasurer thinks of the Prime Minister.

In his previous speech on a censure motion in this place, after talking at vast length about his detailed study of the environmental report, which he alleged no one on this side of the House had read, he managed to make the earth-shattering revelation to the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) that there was no gold at Coronation Hill and suggested that the honourable member was a fool not to know that. I am pleased that he has at least used this opportunity in the debate to correct his absurd error. I could not believe that the leader of a major party in this country, who is persistently raising that as an issue in this place, would stand in that sort of ignorance. SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members should take no comfort from the results of the South Australian election. I recollect the surge to us which occurred in 1983 when the Australian Labor Party was elected. At that time Liberal State governments were going down like ninepins, not on the basis of Grey Power, Democrats or any other preferences but, rather, on the basis of people moving from the Liberal column into the Labor column. Liberal governments lost office in Victoria, Western Australia and federally. The current situation is that those Labor governments are being re-elected and joined by others, including the Labor Party in Tasmania. The Labor Government has survived in South Australia for the third time in succession and, following the election in Queensland on Saturday, we will see a Labor government there also. This is the great run-on, the great surge of support for the Liberal Party!

We do not obscure the fact that certain features of the policies we are obliged to pursue do concern people, and we thoroughly acknowledge that point. Tough decisions must be made in government and they have to be explained to people if the government wishes to be re-elected. It is easy for the Opposition to criticise this Government and to state an effective position which can secure this Government's political defeat. Why is it that the Opposition wins every public opinion poll and every by-election, but when people are asked whether or not they wish to appoint the Opposition as a government-in other words, to stand aside from the politics of protest and actually enter the lists to vote for a government-they will not support the Opposition? Even if they intend to support the Opposition parties when a government is at stake voters prefer to go through two or three different routes before listing them. That occurs because the Opposition stands for nothing; it has no policy which people believe will remove the dilemma in which they find themselves. The voters will adopt that position when they go to the polls.

The election will be well into next year. The fact is that the Opposition has had a run as a result of a couple of insubstantial points included in its Economic Action Plan. However, I suggest that honourable members opposite begin to read the press commentary on that plan, because members of the press are beginning to ask questions. They ask us the question about interest rates and say, `What is your position on interest rates?'. We say, `Interest rates are at this level. We know that it is a difficult level to live with, but they will not go higher because we are in a situation where we are keeping fiscal policy tight and we are pursuing a wages policy that keeps interest rates at least at a level where they do not blow out to blazes'. This is not a stand pat position; rather, this position is a product of disciplined Budget policy over a number of years that has turned the Opposition's record deficit into a record surplus. As a result, this Government can at least have some handle, in a deregulated environment, on a blow-out in interest rates.

Members of the press understand and will ensure that the public also understands that, if the Government does not produce further real reductions in wages and does not cut fiscal policies much further, it can pursue only one policy on interest rates and that is massive increases in interest to flatten the economy as it did on a previous occasion. It is not as though there is no evidence of the Opposition's practices on that in the past; they are well known. That strategy was pursued by the Liberal Party in the past and it will be pursued again. It is Banquo's ghost at the feast of the economic action plan; it sits there subliminally between the lines, haunting the people who put it forward, haunting them so severely that they do not dare confront the press at any press conference. They do not dare confront anyone who will subject them to systematic questioning. It is all right to have a public meeting in which they march in, make the speech and march out again. Adolf Hitler knew all about that practice at Nuremberg. He knew that at a public meeting one should not subject oneself to a question unless it is an arranged question. The policy is to march in, big chant and march out. That is the way in which the Liberal Party conducts its public meetings and the way in which it puts itself forward for a public test. Honourable members opposite know that if they presented for questioning they could not stand up.

They also know that if their Leader were presented for questioning, devastation would result. He cannot obfuscate. The honourable member for Wentworth knows enough in the area of economic policy to obfuscate somewhat by getting off the subject when he is subject to a hard question. The Leader of the Opposition has no chance at all. What comfort would any person have in the alternative government when he looks at the debate which has taken place today? The Leader of the Opposition made a speech that he has made on two previous occasions, last week and earlier than that. Not a word was different. He even had the decency to acknowledge that, as on two or three separate occasions during his speech he said, `As I said last time'. I suppose next time he will say, `As I said last time, the time before that, and the time before that'. He will say that he has run out of the capacity to use 20 minutes in any other way.

The Leader of the Opposition is in that situation because he does not understand what he is handling. What comfort does it give people about to cast a vote to know that if they voted for the Opposition they would put into power a Prime Minister who does not understand what his subordinates are doing and who would preside over a policy which can work only if housing interest rates go well into the low 20s and if rates on business go about four or five percentage points higher than that? The policy of the Opposition cannot work without that happening. As a result, the economy will be flattened. Where will the compassion of the Opposition be then? What will it do as it sees the people go from their houses on to the streets; as it sees people join the dole queues, as they did once before; as it sees the kids deprived of life chances, as they were by that extended period of youth unemployment that the Liberal and National parties invoked when they came into office? What will the Opposition do for them? What will it say to them?

We have some idea of where the Opposition stands on compassion from some of the policies that are outlined in the Economic Action Plan. It says: `Yaboo sux! The people don't really like the unemployed, so we will take from the unemployed and give to John Elliott and the rest of his mates in the Fosters Liberal Party a massive capital gains benefit'. That is what we understand now by Liberal Party compassion. The Liberal Party will take from the unemployed to give to John Elliott; that is its compassion. That is what it invites us to applaud in this place; it invites the galleries and the public to applaud it. The evidence of its compassion is to ladle money into John Elliott's trough and into the troughs of those of his ilk, ripping it from the poor while it does so. That is an indication of how members of the Opposition would deal with the situation when they confront the problems which will occur as a result of their pursuing massive interest rate policies.

There are months to go before the next election. Members opposite should not think for one minute that they will get away with meandering into the polls, having said nothing about where they intend to take interest rates. They should not think for one minute that they will get away with that. These days campaigns are different. They are not pursued in the way they were in the past. We keep winning elections because we address people where they are. The honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) has been amused by the fact that I doorknock my constituency. As I cheerfully own up to that, I inform him that I have doorknocked my constituency in every campaign for every election that I have won. I inform the honourable member for Tangney-textbook Tangney as he was described recently because he takes his policy from a textbook; if he took it from any decent textbook he would know this-that doorknocking is the sort of thing a member of parliament does. A member of parliament confronts his constituents on the doorstep, he explains the policy of his party and points to the policy of other parties; he is prepared to put himself at risk in relation to the policies. I have doorknocked my constituency before every election and I will continue to do so. I also doorknock between elections.

The people in my electorate tell me that they find interest rates hard to bear. Many of them tell me that they have found circumstances difficult to handle. However, they also say that the Opposition is led by a will-o'-the-wisp and that they cannot support it. They say that there is nothing that can be done about an Opposition that will not tell people what it will do, that has no plan for the future except persiflage in this place and further obfuscation out on the hustings. The Opposition has a total unwillingness to present itself to a decent test. In marginal seats, the electors know that their votes will make a substantial difference. Every time that is the case, the wing collapses, as it did in South Australia. We lost a couple of good members in South Australia at the recent State election and the swings against them were 2 or 3 per cent. If the Liberal Party gains a couple of per cent from us in our Federal marginal seats, it will not be elected. It may win a few seats, but it will not become the government. The reason for that is that the electors make a serious study of what the parties offer. I will tell the House one other thing they say to me. They have a few views about the honourable member for Tangney. They feel that he has a bit of growing up to do. Ironically, they also had a few views about the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). They thought he was a decent man; they were probably right in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —They ring me and say, `When are we going to get rid of him?'.

—The only way people will ever get to talk to the honourable member for Tangney is if they ring him up because they will not see him on their doorsteps. They will not see the honourable member for Tangney at any public meeting in his constituency. If they are lucky, they might get through to him on the telephone. The Opposition cannot conceal it by the sorts of policies it produces here. It will not be able to conceal it, given the fact that its leader is completely incapable of explaining economic policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion is contemptible. Members opposite have dragged into the motion on a general debate on the economy a view they have on the subject of the recent airline dispute. Had the Government not stood firm, had the airlines not stood firm, there would have been the potential for a blow-out in wages similar to that which occurred when the Liberal Party was in office in 1981-82. That is what was at stake. The Government did not decide that it would be a nice thing if members of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots stopped flying aircraft; it did not think that it would be a good idea. That has never been the Government's position. The Government decided that the issue had to be taken on because the consequences of failing to do so would include major economic damage, if not ruin, to this nation. We took it on for no other reason. No serious economic commentator disagreed with us in that regard.

The Opposition urges us to talk to the pilots when we are so far down the road and something like 40 per cent of the required work force has already been recruited. On what basis? The basis for negotiation put forward to us is: `We will hold off until after Christmas and then go back to things as normal. TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the twenty-first and twenty-second reports of the Committee for 1989, relating to, respectively, housing development for the Defence Housing Authority at Randwick, Holsworthy and East Hills, Sydney and the development of Commonwealth Government Centre, stage 2, Townsville.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Defence Housing Authority proposal involves housing developments at Randwick, Holsworthy and East Hills, Sydney, at an estimated cost of $131.84m at July 1989 prices. At present a need exists to acquire suitable housing for defence personnel in the Sydney metropolitan area. Over the next three to five years it is proposed to develop sites at Randwick, Holsworthy and East Hills for integrated defence-civilian housing. It is proposed to build approximately 100 medium density townhouses at Randwick. At Holsworthy 1,500 residential allotments will provide a mix of conventional, cottage and medium density housing, while the East Hills site will consist of 400 residential allotments providing a mix of housing. The developments will be undertaken through a joint venture arrangement between one or more developers and the Defence Housing Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: The East Hills site includes an area of freshwater wetlands-believed to be the best surviving example in the Sydney area. The Defence Housing Authority has acknowledged the environmental significance of these wetlands and has assured the Committee that there is no intention to seek rezoning of this area for residential purposes. The Committee agreed with the Defence Housing Authority and various environmental groups at East Hills that development should be excluded from the forested slopes down to the Georges River and that a corridor linking the environmentally sensitive vegetation areas should be maintained.

The report relating to the stage 2 development of the Commonwealth Government Centre, Townsville, is for the construction and fitout of a 12-storey office building of 12,600 square metres on Commonwealth- owned land adjacent to the existing Commonwealth Centre. The building will be specifically designed to meet the Australian Taxation Office's accommodation requirements to service the northern Queensland region, particularly as a result of its computer redevelopment and re-equipment program. The Department of Administrative Services informed the Committee that the existing scattered mix of owned and leased accommodation occupied by the Australian Taxation Office in Townsville is not conducive to administrative efficiency.

The Committee believes that the consolidation of the Australian Taxation Office in one building will improve administrative efficiency and security of operations, allow for the rationalisation of other Commonwealth tenancies and effect significant reductions in the rent bill by relinquishment of approximately 6,500 square metres of leased accommodation in Townsville. The Committee accepted the advice of the Department of Administrative Services that the construction of a Commonwealth-owned building is the most cost effective method of satisfying the office accommodation requirements of the Commonwealth in Townsville. The Committee was informed that savings to the Commonwealth for equivalent leased space over a 15-year period is estimated at $21.2m at current prices. I commend the reports to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, I present the Committee's report, entitled Rail: Five systems-one solution, on the efficiency of Australian National's east-west oper- ations, together with the minutes of pro- ceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure deals primarily with ways of improving the efficiency of the east-west freight and passenger operations of the Australian National Railways Commission. Our terms of reference also charged the Committee with considering two other major issues: the transfer of terminal facilities from Broken Hill to Parkes, and greater integration of intersystem operations. In the course of the inquiry a number of other issues arose which demanded our attention. These included: proposals for a national freight consortium; road-rail cost recovery; the subsidy paid to the transport industry; and ways to reduce the amount of freight being carried on the national road system. We gave a great deal of attention to these issues because of their close relationship with the inquiry's terms of reference and because of their importance to the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: In the context of improving the east-west efficiency of Australian National (AN), our terms of reference made particular mention of the transfer of terminal facilities from Broken Hill to Parkes. It is important that this matter be fully explained. There is no AN terminal at Broken Hill which could be moved to Parkes, or anywhere else. AN has no staff or facilities of its own there. AN pays the State Rail Authority of New South Wales for any services carried out by SRA at Broken Hill. As the result of the Booz Allen and Hamilton Inc. review of the operations of SRA, significant reductions are being made to staff numbers at Broken Hill and other places on the main east-west rail corridor. AN has proposed a number of ways its efficiency in this corridor could be improved and up to 50 positions at Broken Hill have been identified as affected by these changes. These operational and other changes are dealt with in chapter 3 of our report. Discussions between AN and SRA are proceeding to identify any savings which can be achieved, and the benefits will be shared between the systems, according to their agreement.

The Committee noted, both in the submissions from and in the evidence taken at Broken Hill on 7 June 1989, the attitudes of that city. The Mayor, the Chamber of Commerce, the Barrier Industrial Council and private citizens all expressed concerns about the impact of cuts to employment in that city. The New South Wales Government and the SRA have given guarantees about retraining and relocation of staff. We can only hope that these guarantees are honoured.

The conclusions and recommendations in this report deal, firstly, with the various operational problems which exist in the main east-west corridor. In particular, we believe that the proposals AN has made to improve efficiency at and east of Broken Hill should proceed and that New South Wales should receive assistance from diesel fuel excise payments to fund the necessary work in its territory. Studies on the feasibility of standardising the Melbourne-Adelaide route should continue because of the national benefits that this would confer and there should be studies of the feasibility of bypasses of the main line at both Kalgoorlie and Port Augusta.

The most important conclusions and recommendations relate to inter-system freight and passenger operations, the subsidy paid to road transport and funding for upgrading railway infrastructure. It is a matter of concern to the Committee that enormous sums have been spent on the national road system at a time when so few excise payments have been returned to rail systems to improve and upgrade the necessary infrastructure. I believe that some of my colleagues will deal with these issues in more detail.

It is customary to thank those who have been involved in the preparation of a report. I would like to acknowledge the work done for members and staff by the Transport Office of the House of Representatives. The printing staff gave a great deal of help, pleasantly and willingly, at various stages. At different stages Valma Buck, Tracy Cumberland, Laura Gillies, Marlene Lyons and Natalie Raine performed nobly on the keyboard, with Di Morrison of Joint House, who did a wonderful job transforming the draft for printing. Our special gratitude is due to our adviser, David Baussmann, and to the staff of the secretariat, June Murphy and Patrick Regan. They did all the planning for our trips, researched, drafted and typed the report and were pleasant and helpful companions to us all.

This has been an interesting and revealing inquiry. We all hope that this report will make a worthwhile contribution to an important national issue, the future of rail in Australia. Finally, I would like to thank all of my colleagues on the Committee, particularly the members of the subcommittee, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) and the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil). They cooperated fully, both at hearings and in the preparation of the report, and assisted me greatly in the finalisation of the report. I believe we arrived at a report which is worth commending not only to the House but to the Government for adoption.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I commence my remarks by saying `well done' to the members of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure for the report Rail: Five systems-one solution that was tabled a few moments ago in the House. SPEECH.PARA: The future of railway has, I believe, been grossly underrated in Australia for many years. I have a personal belief that railway in this country has tremendous potential which can be achieved if both State and Federal governments are prepared to face up to reality and make the hard, necessary decisions to implement the types of changes and reforms that are needed. At present the railway systems throughout Australia are in general subsidised. I doubt whether one could honestly say that any railway system in Australian is not being subsidised in one form or another. As the Industries Assistance Commission pointed out in its annual report tabled only a couple of weeks ago, if we can reform some of the areas of our transport infrastructure-areas such as railway, waterfront, coastal shipping and so forth-and look at other factors within out transport infrastructure, we can give a $9 billion a year boost to the gross domestic product of Australia each and every year. The types of changes being spoken of in this report lead to those sorts of potential gains down the track if we can get governments to take up the opportunities that are present today.

Throughout the world there is a recognition of the importance of railway. As airways become more congested and airports become more congested and difficult to build, in places such as Europe people are starting to look to the potential of railway. Indeed, that potential is now being realised and railways are finding a new life. People are finding that railways can operate profitably and that private enterprise can be allowed to operate within existing railway services. Those private railways can operate profitably and provide a very good service. This is not just being done in Europe, in countries such as France, with its TGV system. There is also the very fast train in Japan. There is even talk of our own very fast train, running initially between Sydney and Melbourne.

So the future of railway is being recognised as a future with great potential. That is what this report is about. It has a number of features which I am very pleased to see. Of course, I am disappointed not to see some features written into the report. I want briefly to touch on the features I am very pleased to see. One is the fact that the report believes that Australian National, the Commonwealth's railway operation, has a very important role in the future. Australian National, as the report suggests, needs to have a central controlling role in interstate passenger and freight services in the future. If it can be given that role, I believe Australian National will perform the task more than admirably because Australian National is now regarded as being probably the most efficient railway operation in Australia. I was also pleased to see talk of the amalgamation of depots at Kalgoorlie, the transfer of terminal facilities to Parkes and the works that have been recommended to take place from Broken Hill eastwards.

There are some disappointments in the report. I am particularly disappointed that there is no discussion of the possible role of private enterprise in Australia's railway future, particularly within the operations of Australian National. As I mentioned a few months ago, the experiences of Europe indicate that there is a very genuine, real role for private enterprise in our rail system. If we include private enterprise in our rail system it will help us pay for the necessary improvements that are needed to our rail systems and help us to become more competitive and more efficient in our railway operations. It will also help our railway operations to become more reliable. I believe it is terribly important that we bring private enterprise into the operation of railway services throughout Australia.

I am a little disappointed that some anti-road freight sentiment seems to be expressed in the report. I propose another argument-that is, that we ought to be giving greater priority to the transport infrastructure of Australia. We should not be arguing that we should be shuffling existing funds from road construction to railway improvements; we should take another argument altogether and say that we need to give greater national priority to improving the transport infrastructure of Australia, part of which includes improving our railway and part of which includes improving our road services.

I think that if we take this line we will achieve more results, because many people today would say that road freight people contribute a tremendous amount towards the cost of provision and upgrading of road services in Australia and that railway is a very grossly oversubsidised operation. Either way, let us argue for more priority for national transport infrastructure rather than shuffling the cards between ourselves to try to take money from roads and give it to rail.

There are also some other very interesting elements that I would like to see brought into the debate about railway, and that is the use of B-doubles. Of course, B-doubles, which provide a 20 per cent increase in efficiency, can supplement railway operations in Australia. I see that there has been some discussion about the Melbourne to Adelaide standard gauge rail track. I believe that that was part of the Australian Labor Party's commitment when it first went into government in 1983-a commitment yet to be fulfilled, as is a commitment to a rail service between Alice Springs and Darwin.

Either way, the coalition is pleased to see this type of discussion come into this Parliament. It is pleased to see that these types of recommendations are being made. The best thing we can say is that we are pleased with certain elements of the report. The basis of the report is good, but it falls short in a number of areas which we believe are important. We give the commitment to member of the Committee and members of the Parliament that the coalition will pursue this line of work when we get into government. We will take up the hard issues and we will put into action some of the thoughts and expressions made by members of this Committee. We believe that by so doing we will help to transform and reform Australia's transport infrastructure to make us more efficient as a nation producing products to sell overseas.

I would also like to say `well done' to the staff of the Committee. The report is well put together, well written, well researched and, from all reports, has been put together by a very cooperative and very professional group of people.

This, it seems to me, is what AN has done, and done very successfully since 1978. Some evidence was given to us about a couple of matters which I would like to touch on: bypasses from the main line at Kalgoorlie and Port Augusta, and standard- isation of the Melbourne-Adelaide route. While there may well be considerable benefits to the local communities if freight trains in particular bypassed Kalgoorlie and Port Augusta, AN has not to date been very interested in either proposal. Our report recommends that the feasibility, costs and benefits of these proposals should be further investigated. Standardisation of the Melbourne-Adelaide route would link all the mainland capitals by standard gauge line. While this would be costly, in our view it is too important to continue to be neglected. some of the other recommendations in this report may seem to be radical. For example, at a time then the emphasis is on efficiency and micro-economic reform, we have recommended retention of the Indian Pacific, Trans Australian and Overland passenger services, which have to be subsidised to the tune of about $60m per year. This is for two reasons; first, these trains do provide a service to various communities; and, second, if the Indian Pacific particularly were to be abolished, it would not be possible to undertake the marketing campaign `Journey of a Lifetime' we have recommended.

The other area where our recommendation could be seen to be radical is in the area of funding for railway infrastructure projects. The Committee believes that as both rail and road pay excise duty on the fuel they use, it is reasonable that both get a fair return from the Federal Government of the amount each has contributed. This simply does not happen. While something like $1.25 billion has been spent on the national road system, little or nothing has been spent on comparable rail projects. The Committee recommends a return to the rail systems of amounts equal to the percentage level of funds available to road from the fuel excise contributed by road. This is hardly unfair or radical, but is very necessary. It is necessary because rail has been denied funds and, more importantly, because of the urgent need to do something about the amount of long-distance freight carried by heavy vehicles which rail should move. That heavy vehicles damage roads and cause noise and other pollution cannot be denied. It is also impossible to ignore the awful accidents on the Pacific and Hume highways-to mention but two-with their tragic consequences for so many innocent people.

In evidence AN estimated that if it could improve its efficiency, it could gain about 50 per cent of the existing road market for the east-west corridor. This would increase its tonnage over a two-year or three-year period by about 85,000 tonnes and take about 3,000 trucks off the highway, which is extremely significant. If this could be done on a national scale, how much safer our highways would be, how much longer they would last and how much money would be available for other desirable projects for the nation. In the context of improving AN's east-west efficiency, this is what we believe should be a national goal: putting rail into its rightful place as the means of transporting long-distance freight. This idea is very well captured by the excellent drawing on the cover of our report. It shows a semi-trailer giving way to a freight train. This is how it must be, to save the country money, to reduce pollution and to improve safety on highways.

It is food for thought that the debate on transport in Australia has escalated in recent months due partly to that horrific bus coach accident north of Grafton and partly to the fact that people are starting to think again about the correct balance between rail and road and the correct policy mix to achieve that balance. If one goes back through history, it is also food for thought that, if the planners of the previous century had got the tramtrack gauge wrong in Melbourne and Bendigo and got the rail gauge right in Victoria, many of the problems faced by this Committee in its inquiry would not have arisen. As I pointed out yesterday morning on Ian McNamara's program Australia All Over, the Melbourne and Bendigo trams run on the New South Wales standard gauge, or the world standard gauge, of 4 feet 8 1/2 inches, whereas the engineers made the rail gauge for Victoria, and subsequently South Australia, the so-called larger and broader gauge, which is 5 feet 3 inches, or whatever is the metric equivalent. That tremendous error has caused great difficulty ever since for the Australian economy and for our transport infrastructure. This report seeks to continue the process of overcoming some of those difficulties.

The fact that a standard gauge runs all the way from Sydney to Perth does not fully overcome the problems confronted by a person sending an average container from Sydney to Perth. Page 9 of the report points out as follows:
As it crosses Australia, it will or could be subjected to the following:
3 totally different non-integrated rail systems (AN, SRA and Westrail);
4 changes of locomotives;
5 different safe working systems;
6 different sizes of loading gauge;
10 or more different engineering standards of the basic standard gauge rail track . . .

It also involves many hours waiting at sidings and junctions for crew changes, refuelling, inspections and passing of other trains along the single gauge track involved. Indeed, as far as the system stands at the moment, even if no train is coming the other way, a super freighter rolling out of Parkes to Broken Hill is required to stop 11 times between Parkes and Broken Hill, in order to carry out the antiquated safe working system at each of the sidings between Parkes and Broken Hill. That process incurs great cost in terms of bringing a 3,000-tonne train to a halt. It affects the ticket and staff systems. It involves obtaining clearance for the next section of track and then accelerating. It is an incredible process. Ian Hill and others associated with the State Rail Authority of New South Wales are working on this problem.

This report provides a very clear blueprint as to how to overcome that problem and other problems associated with the east-west corridor. Time does not permit my dwelling on all the detailed aspects but I highlight the fact that an $18m package is identified in this report. It provides for the introduction of long trains west of Parkes, with marshalling facilities at Parkes at a cost of $3m; crossing loops between Parkes and Broken Hill at a cost of $1.2m; reduced transit times between Sydney and Perth through high speed bogies at a cost of $1m; and an improved system of train order working between Parkes and Broken Hill at a cost of $5m. That would save two hours in transit time for every train. The package also provides for through-working of locomotives and mainline refuelling at Broken Hill at a cost of $750,000. That aspect has been highlighted by the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks). The package would also develop loading facilities at Parkes at a cost of $2m at Goobang Junction and increased terminal capacity at Chullora at a cost of $5m. The total cost of the package is $18m.

I mention those points in detail because they involve places that are close to my own electorate. The package stops short of the more comprehensive proposal which I want to see evolve at Parkes, which by its very location at a major junction of lines going north, east, south and west, lends itself to becoming a major intermodal component as further progress is made with redeveloping and revamping rail transport in Australia.

Parkes has a key role to play. I know that the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) shares my views on this matter. I believe that Parkes should be a major forwarding depot. The double-stack container super freighters should power out of Parkes to Perth and run as super-freighter unit trainloads without interference between Parkes and Perth. Efficiencies would flow as a result. Parkes is not in my electorate, but I fully recognise the synchronised energy available from that development at Parkes. This report touches on that matter and affirms my views. It perhaps stops short of laying down the massive development which we would like to see occur, but it provides the initial basis for the development which, as it builds momentum, and because so much activity and potential are available at Parkes, will follow quite naturally.

Australia's rail system is chaotic. There are five different systems on mainland Australia and quite often they are in absolute competition with each other rather than being a coordinated and integrated approach. I can point to example after example where problems occur at each of the borders, including shunting problems at Albury-Wodonga. There are problems with the arrangements associated with shunting and the through-running of locomotives, but some progress has been made in that regard. Problems are also experienced at Broken Hill, Kalgoorlie and elsewhere and they are identified throughout this report.

Australia must grasp the nettle now and provide a basis for revamping rail before it is too late. Europe is undergoing a massive swing back to rail involving containerised freight and high-speed trains. The French TGV system has operated successfully and at a profit for about five years with an impeccable safety record. In Australia we also have the opportunity to make that progress. The report provides a blueprint for revamping conventional rail. I understand that this week there will be a further progress report released by the very fast train syndicate. It is to be hoped that it will provide more information and that there will be the prospect of seeing that project proceed between Sydney and Melbourne, subject to its stacking up economically and environmentally. A Senate committee is undertaking a detailed investigation in that respect.

I remind the House that a steel wheel on a steel rail has about one-seventh or one-tenth of the friction of a rubber-tyred wheel on a bitumen surface. In that statistic, we see the reason that rail is so efficient and economic if operated properly and in conjunction with road networks. Australia must act to get in place the right transport policy mix before it is too late. That correct policy mix must contain a considerable boost to the priority for efficient, effective, conventional rail.

However, when one tries to find out where the subsidies in relation to rail lie, one finds that it is almost impossible to obtain a reliable figure. I think I am right in saying that the Inter-State Commission has done some work on that, but a lot more work needs to be done on the distribution of subsidies so that we can ultimately understand the true economics of this issue of rail transport. There are long-term economic advantages in restructuring the railways in Australia and ensuring that they can become viable, but there is still a long way to go.

I would like to make three brief points. What the report recommends is very important. I hope that the Federal Government and the relevant State governments will take up the recommendations of the Committee. The first issue is that of coordination. It is absurd that five different rail systems are responsible for interstate freight in this country. What is equally absurd is the way in which some State governments came before our Committee and said that the way to solve the problem of five different systems was to establish a sixth system. There are two things wrong with that. The first is obviously that when the problem is five systems, it is absurd to propose a sixth. The second is a problem of logic. We already have Australian National. If we were to establish a new national freight system, Australian National would lose its point to exist. Its whole raison d'etre would disappear. So there is a contradiction in the argument of some of the States that we should establish that sixth system. I hope that that argument, which has been put forward by some of the States, will be strongly rejected by the Federal Government and that those States will reconsider their positions in the years ahead and realise that, whatever may be in the interests of pork-barrelling politics in those individual States, that is not in the long term interests of Australia as a nation. State governments have to think more about Australia as a nation, not just about their regional and parochial interests.

The second issue I would like to allude to briefly is that of investment. This report talks about the need for an increase in investment in railways, but it does not actually say where the money is to come from. I think that, in a way, that is a pity, because I have a view about where the money could come from which I know other people on the Committee were reluctant to endorse. I think that railways is one area where we can very comfortably move towards privatisation, albeit partial privatisation in the initial stages. It may be impossible early on to sell the permanent way, but the whole concept of privatising the rolling stock and, perhaps, the locomotives-if you like, privatising the trains but not the track-is something that we have to look at very carefully in the years ahead. That is one way we will get additional capital invested in railways. In a sense, there is already market pressure for that to happen. We saw many examples of that around Australia. We spoke to major private transport companies who expressed an interest in remaining involved in railways, getting further involved in railways and investing further in railways, but the whole process is inhibited by the fact that railways in Australia are effectively nationalised. By being nationalised, there are of course two problems. One is that politics has intervened in so many decisions about the efficiency of railways and the other is that there has simply been an inadequacy of capital investment.

Finally, I want to allude briefly to the issue of passenger services. I am very dubious about the viability of passenger services, and I point out some information in the report: for travel from Sydney to Perth it would be cheaper to give somebody a first-class air ticket than to provide the subsidy to travel by train. We really have to think very carefully about where we are spending taxpayers' money and whether that really makes any sense.

In conclusion, let me say that I enjoyed very much participating in this work. As a South Australian I am very optimistic that, if this report is implemented, South Australia will become the railway capital of Australia, with the headquarters of Australian National already established there. If Australian National is to become, as it should, the national interstate freight operator for railways in Australia, South Australia will become the freight capital of Australia. That will provide more jobs in South Australia. It is with great regret that I report to the House that the South Australian Government did not even bother, despite an invitation, to produce a submission to this Committee. That was very negligent of it. However, once more I congratulate the staff and the members of the Committee on all that they did. I hope the Government will implement the bulk of the recommendations of this report.

DEBATE.TITLE: REDEVELOPMENT OF AERONAUTICAL RESEARCH LABORATORY SITE, FISHERMENS BEND, VICTORIA

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Redevelopment of Aeronautical Research Laboratory site, Fishermens Bend, Victoria.

The Aeronautical Research Laboratory (ARL) is part of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation of the Department of Defence. ARL's terms of reference are to develop, maintain and exploit scientific and technological skills and facilities in areas generally central to the military, air vehicles and relevant aspects of weapons for the benefit of the Australian Defence Force. Existing laboratory and office accommodation at ARL is crowded and unsuitable for effective research, development and investigation in a number of areas of technology.

Until 30 June 1988 ARL operated from a 9.55-hectare site at Fishermens Bend, Port Melbourne, leased from the Victorian Government for a period of 50 years. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) occupied an adjacent 2.75-hectare site also leased from the Victorian Government under the same arrangement. On expiry of the leases on 30 June 1988, the entire 12.3-hectare site was purchased by the Commonwealth from the State Government. The Department of Defence is planning to purchase usable ex-CSIRO buildings on the site this financial year with the aim of refurbishing them to accommodate the expansion of ARL. The redevelopment proposal also includes refurbishment of some existing ARL buildings. The redevelopment proposal has evolved from a need to rationalise the operation and management of the research facility. It will provide badly needed laboratory and office space and enable staff of the scientific divisions to be collocated. This, in turn, will enable other buildings to be appropriately modified to provide more flexibility and efficiency and assist ARL to meet its research and development objectives.

Health and safety surveys and site investigations commissioned by Australian Construction Services, and coordinated by Scientific Services Laboratories, identified areas of hazardous chemical and radiation contamination on the ex-CSIRO site. Specifically, asbestos and dangerous wastes have been found in or near buildings previously used by CSIRO. The asbestos found in some buildings will be removed during the refurbishment of those buildings and recommendations have been made regarding the management of organic constituents found in soil surrounding a former disposal facility.

The third item highlighted through the site investigations was the presence of low levels of radiation within or near 10 buildings. This radioactive waste will be removed from the site by the CSIRO, which has advised ARL that this will be achieved by the end of the year. The Department of Defence will monitor and survey the removal of the contaminants from the site. I can assure the House that all appropriate action has been taken and that the proviso written into the environmental certificate of compliance that construction not proceed until the site is cleared of contaminants will be strictly observed.

The project will consist largely of refurbishment and demolition works and will provide functional laboratory facilities to support the advanced technologies embodied in recent aircraft acquisitions, such as the FA18 fighter and the Black Hawk and Seahawk helicopters. The works will also rectify temporary arrangements for laboratories, workshops and offices that have evolved over the past 40 years and rationalise facilities and accommodation. To put the importance of these proposed works into perspective, seven of the eight Australian Defence Force priority capability areas, as identified in the Defence White Paper of 1987, involved aircraft and air operations which have required or will require support from the ARL work programs. Approval of the proposed work is necessary for ARL to progress current and planned work programs to meet national defence objectives.

The scope of the proposed work includes demolition of seven ARL and 19 ex-CSIRO substandard buildings and annexes to two buildings; and refurbishment of five existing buildings on the ex-CSIRO site and four existing ARL buildings. Also included is the provision of roads and car parking, additional electrical power to refurbished buildings, extension of the existing ARL security system to ex-CSIRO buildings, and extension of the communication ducting network. A feasibility study of the site redevelopment included the inspection of buildings on both the ARL and ex-CSIRO sites and buildings identified as suitable for continued use undergoing structural inspection. Results of these inspections have shown that sufficient of the existing CSIRO buildings can be modified, at reasonable cost, to satisfy current and to a certain degree future ARL space requirements. The total useable floor area available to ARL currently is 33,700 square metres. This will increase by around 17 per cent to 39,500 square metres once refurbishment of the combined ARL-CSIRO site is complete. This increase in area is necessary to provide ARL with essential and specific purpose facilities and accommodation.

The limit of cost estimate for the proposed work, at December 1988 prices, is $16.2m and comprises $13.9m for building refurbishment and modification and $2.3m for site works and services. The work will be undertaken in two phases to accommodate funding arrangements of ARL. Phase A, $8.5m, will commence in 1990-91 and phase B, $7.7m, is planned for commencement after 1994. The proposed work is expected to provide employment on site for some 50 people and opportunities for the local building industry.
I table selected plans for the proposed redevelopment of the ARL site and I commend the motion to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: REDEVELOPMENT OF TERMINAL FACILITIES AT ALICE SPRINGS AIRPORT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Redevelopment of terminal facilities at Alice Springs Airport.

This proposed work was recommended by the Public Works Committee in its report of 21 November 1989 and it involves the redevelopment of terminal facilities at Alice Springs Airport. The existing building, which was built in 1963, has already been extended twice. It now contains some 1,460 square metres of covered space but excessive overcrowding is common due to the high levels of sustained growth over many years. The terminal now handles some 960 passengers in a peak hour and annual passenger numbers have increased from 210,000 in 1980 to 509,000 in 1988. This has resulted in airline passenger handling areas operating well below acceptable standards.

Airlines use the airport as a hub allowing interconnections between flights from Cairns, Sydney, Darwin, Adelaide, Melbourne, Perth and Yulara and their operations result in severe overcrowding of the terminal. The Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) is proposing a new terminal and surrounding infrastructure at an indicative cost of $20m at July 1989 prices. The proposed terminal is designed to handle some 1,500 passengers in a peak hour made up of 511 arrivals, 513 transfers and 445 departures.

The conceptual design takes into account forecast passenger and aircraft movements, the space requirements requested by both Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines and forecast aircraft parking requirements for the the mid to late 1990s. The design also allows for expansion should further major airlines seek to operate through Alice Springs after airline deregulation. To date the Federal Airports corporation has received no firm proposals and it is therefore unwilling to commit itself to expenditure that may not be justified.

The work comprises a new terminal of approximately 9,000 square metres, a new access road system, associated landscaped vehicle parking areas, covered walkways between the terminal and airport apron, and the upgrading of engineering services. The Federal Airports Corporation intends to start construction at the end of this year with works to be completed in mid-1991. I repeat: the Federal Airports Corporation intends to start construction at the end of the year with works to be completed in mid-1991.

The proposal was referred to the Northern Territory Conservation Commission, the Australian Heritage Commission and the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Authority, all of which judged the project environmentally acceptable. During the Public Works Committee hearing, the Institute of Aboriginal Development proposed inclusion of a mural in the terminal building. The Federal Airports Corporation has agreed to this proposal and is waiting for the Institute of Aboriginal Development to send it details of the design.

The Public Works Committee in its report commented on two aspects of the proposal, the first being the cost of landscaping the terminal environs. The Federal Airports Corporation, as suggested, is approaching the Northern Territory Government and the Alice Springs Town Council for a financial contribution. But the FAC believes that this unique beautification will be a significant attraction to visitors as it will represent the beauty of the central Australian environment.

The second aspect was the recommendation that the Federal Airports Corporation should prepare a master plan for Alice Springs Airport. The Federal Airports Corporation will undertake this task as soon as practicable. The proposal will be funded from non-Budget sources and will incorporate measures to maximise commercial returns to the FAC. The proposal will assist the Northern Territory by boosting construction activity and by providing a more attractive gateway to the many internationally renowned tourist attractions in central Australia. It will generate work for an average of 100 on-site construction workers, peaking at about 240. This project is another example of the Federal Labor Government's ongoing commitment to the people of the Northern Territory. I think the Public Works Committee for its report, its expeditious treatment of the matter and its hearings. I commend the motion to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPANSION OF INTERNATIONAL TERMINAL FACILITIES, MELBOURNE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Expansion of international terminal facilities, Melbourne Airport.

This proposed work recommended by the Public Works Committee involves the expansion by the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) of the international terminal at Melbourne Airport. The Melbourne international terminal was opened in 1970 and is now recognised as Australia's second busiest terminal. It was originally designed to process, on average, 1,000 arriving and departing passengers per hour. Regularly, 1,800 passengers per hour are now processed. During some periods when off-schedule arrivals occur the demand on the building can reach peak loads as high as 1,900 arriving passengers per hour. Peaks of this magnitude are causing deterioration in the levels of service provided to passengers and inconvenience to airline operations and other terminal users.

To overcome this problem the FAC developed a concept plan for the expansion of the international terminal complex at Melbourne Airport to meet current and forecast growth demands for passenger facilities and aircraft parking requirements to beyond the year 2000. The development of this proposal will result in increased handling capacities within the terminal. Instead of processing only 900 arriving and 900 departing passengers per hour, staff will be able to process 1,800 arriving and 1,800 departing passengers per hour. The proposal will be implemented in phases over the next six years for overall completion in 1995.

A program has been developed by the FAC to match the provision of facilities with demand whilst generating funds to assist the financing of further development. The project will provide an additional six B747-400 air bridge connected gates and a further two aircraft stand-off positions. It will involve new building construction of 28,100 square metres, the complete refurbishment of 35,100 square metres of the existing building, and work associated with the provision of additional building services. The Federal Airports Corporation estimates the cost of development at $170m at December 1988 prices.

Phase 1, involving the expenditure of $48.9m, will involve the infill of 450 square metres of garden courtyard at the departures level and its incorporation into the departure hall. It will also involve the enclosure of some 2,000 square metres of the existing observation deck on the departure level and the provision of shop fronts for leasing to retailers and other tenants. It will also involve the relocation of stairs and escalators connecting with the ground floor arrivals hall, first floor departure hall and the second floor to provide more efficient circulation, particularly at the departures level.

The infill of the concourse at arrival and departure levels to allow relocation of outwards immigration and Customs services and of transit escalators to allow the development of an efficient retail area in the departure hall will also be incorporated in phase 1. It is planned for completion by the end of 1990. Further phases will progressively achieve completion of all the stated improvements by 1995. Phase 1 will employ an average on-site work force of 65 people, peaking at 130, while the total project is likely to employ, all up, about 425 workers on site, which should peak at about 700. The Committee expresses no reservations about the proposal. I thank the Public Works Committee for its report and commend the motion to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 2 November.
Consideration of Senate's amendment.
Senate's amendment-
Page 4, clause 4, after proposed subsection 221ec (9), add the following new subsection:
`` `(10) This section does not apply to:
(a) a public hospital;
(b) a public benevolent institution;
(c) a public university.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendment be disagreed to.

The Government's reason for rejecting the amendment is that the pay-as-you-earn (PAYE) money to be remitted to the Australian Taxation Office is not money that belongs to a group employer; therefore, the status of the employer, that is, the public hospital, the public benefit institution or the public university, is not a matter of principle regarding the timing of remittances. The PAYE money withheld is money to be forwarded to the Australian Taxation Office for payment of employees' future tax liability.

The Government is of the view that no case can be made for allowing an employer to retain the money longer than is necessary. In a perfect world the money should be paid over by an employer as soon as it is withheld. However, administrative considerations in respect of both the employer and the Australian Taxation Office require some time lag between collection and remittance. The change announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his Budget Speech was in the context that the deferral of tax payments arises with the present monthly remittance arrangements and that a new requirement on major employers reduced this deferral.

The amendment would reduce the effectiveness of the Budget measure. In money terms, the amendment would reduce the revenue gained from the measure by $50m. The Opposition sought to argue that the organisations named in the amendment should be exempted from the twice monthly requirement, because they apply their resources to public rather than to private purposes. If this rationale is accepted, the entire public sector-Commonwealth, State and local-should be exempted. The proposed change is the first step in moving larger group employers to a twice monthly system and smaller employers, comprising a majority of remitters, to a less frequent payment system. With this background, the Government rejects the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition disagrees with this motion. In doing so, the Government has overlooked the fact that the Bill refers to group employers and early remitters, such as institutions, which utilise public money for community use. It is against that background that we believe this amendment should go forward and the specific form of the amendment was such, as an amendment to clause 4, that, in addition to subsection 221ec (9) a new subsection (10) should be included so that the Bill would not apply to a public hospital, a public benevolent institution and a public university.

As mentioned by the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) that nonsense was presented in order to prop up and to mislead about a spurious surplus, as the Treasurer has managed to do in a couple of recent Budgets.

I seem to recollect that this legislation was the subject of the guillotine. During the second reading debate I commented that we would be back in this chamber discussing this amendment. The amendment moved and passed in the Senate seeks to exempt hospitals, charitable organisations and universities from the requirements of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill that advance the collection of group deductions under certain circumstances for those institutions that have annual payroll deductions in excess of $5m.
