TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Bill 1989. The object of the Bill is to put into Australian law some provisions that are required before ratification of the recently concluded United Nations Convention against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances.

SPEECH.PARA: The convention requires countries that ratify it to take substantive action to help stamp out the international traffic in narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances, which I will refer to as drugs. This action is in several forms. It will require Australia as a country that is going to ratify the convention to ensure that manufacturing, growing and dealing in drugs and money laundering of drug proceeds are all made criminal offences under domestic law; to ensure that the local courts have jurisdiction over drug crimes; to ensure that there is a domestic law for the tracing, freezing and confiscation of drug proceeds; to ensure that there is an adequate regime for the extradition of drug criminals; to provide other countries with legal assistance in investigations and prosecutions; to provide for good communications, exchange of information, joint task forces, liaison officers, research and training; to identify miscreants by allowing international controlled delivery of drugs; to prevent the diversion of specified substances used in the illicit manufacture of drugs; to prevent the illicit cultivation of and promote the eradication of plants containing narcotic or psychotropic substances; to prevent the commercial carriage of drugs; to promote the proper documentation of drugs lawfully exported; and to suppress the illicit traffic of drugs by sea and air through the mails and in free trade zones and free ports.

They are the objectives that are sought to be achieved by the United Nations Convention against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. Those matters are the matters that Australia will be required to implement within its own law. Many of the obligations assumed by Australia under this convention are in fact already legislated for by State laws and by Federal laws such as the Customs Act, the Proceeds of Crime Act, the Extradition Act and the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act. Other obligations will be implemented by ongoing consultations with the States. The object of those consultations will be to encourage the States to implement those parts of the convention that can be implemented only by State law, and to do this by having their laws comply with the convention. By this Bill the Commonwealth is not overriding any State laws and, indeed, that proposition is at least to some extent enshrined in the Bill itself because the Bill provides in clause 5 (1):
This Act is not intended to exclude or limit the operation of any other law of the Commonwealth or any law of a State or Territory.
Presumably this is not to be one of those cases where the Commonwealth will be using the external affairs power to override State laws.

The area which needs to be legislated for by the Commonwealth, and which is the principal concern of this Bill, is extraterritorial jurisdiction. Enforcing the full international rigour of the convention requires nations to provide for extraterritorial jurisdiction by their courts over drug crimes when the domestic law might not give jurisdiction. Thus the Bill gives Australia extraterritorial jurisdiction over drug crimes in a number of cases and the most important of them are as follows: firstly, where the crime is committed by an Australian national, but committed outside Australia, and in that case normally the Australian courts would not have jurisdiction over it; secondly, where a foreigner commits the crime outside Australia but he is subsequently located in Australia; thirdly, where the conduct in the example given in the second reading speech is growing a crop of a drug where the conduct is engaged in with the view to the commission of a drug crime in Australia; fourthly, aiding and abetting, et cetera, outside Australia the commission of a breach of a State or Territory drug crime; and, fifthly, dealing in drugs on an Australian aircraft or ship. Normally those matters would not come within the jurisdiction of the Australian courts and the object of this Bill, pursuant to the convention, is to bring them within the jurisdiction of the Australian courts, and that is a worthwhile objective.

To maintain a vigorous fight against international drug crimes, these extensions of Australian jurisdiction-for that is what they are, extending the jurisdiction of the Australian courts over new crimes-are, we believe, like the Government, justified. Without them, to give one example, those engaged in hatching a conspiracy on an Australian ship in the Persian Gulf to smuggle drugs into Australia when the ship returns to Australia may not be subject to Australian jurisdiction but, when this amendment becomes law, or when this amendment to the law is implemented, they will of course be subject to Australian jurisdiction, as clearly they should be. The Bill fixes a variety of penalties for these offences, ranging up to life imprisonment, depending on the quantity of drugs involved. As I read it, the penalties are broadly in line with those prescribed under the Customs Act for dealing with similar quantities of drugs.

It is well known that there has been some opposition in certain quarters to the convention on the ground that it perpetuates what is called the law and order approach to drugs which, it is said by those who advance this argument, has not succeeded in stamping out the drug problem. It is argued that we should be looking at what is referred to as decriminalising drugs or legalising them. This has been particularly argued for in the case of heroin. A number of organisations and individuals have been advancing this argument in recent times. The Foundation for Drug Policy, which was established recently, is one such body that has advocated this approach. In other words, the people advocating that sort of argument say that this Bill and the laws associated with it are undesirable and unnecessary, as indeed is the convention, because they perpetuate what is popularly referred to as the law and order approach towards stamping out the drug problem.

Whatever the merits of that argument may be, and some maintain that the argument has merits, the short point we believe is that it is false to suggest that the convention prevents the examination of other options for dealing with the drug problem. There again we find ourselves to this extent on common ground with the Government. Indeed, the most cursory examination of the convention makes it plain that this is the case. The convention provides that, despite the obligation imposed on nation states which are parties to the convention to make drug crimes punishable; nevertheless parties to the convention may, and I quote from the convention, `provide as alternatives to conviction or punishment'-in other words, as alternatives to the law and order approach-`measures such as education, rehabilitation or social reintegration as well as, when the offender is a drug abuser, treatment and after care'. So the convention itself, on its plain terms, throws up as an option an alternative approach to prosecution, conviction and imprisonment, which is legitimised under the convention, of treatment and after-care. So it is quite plain that it does not prevent non-criminal sanctions and it does not prevent non-penal sanctions for abuse of the use of hard drugs.

I understand from the second reading speech that this is the Government's argument, for we were told in the second reading speech that the convention `does not preclude the re-examination of policy in relation to personal use of prohibited drugs'. I say that I understand that this is the Government's view because there seems to be some difference of opinion amongst at least some government officials on this issue. Although, on my interpretation, the convention itself does not prohibit or rule out an alternative approach to dealing with the drug problem, nevertheless it is appropriate to highlight the discrepancy of opinion that seems to be emerging among some government officials.

In particular, we have noticed remarks by the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Chairman of the National Crime Authority. We have noticed that they have been having some publicly expressed differences of opinion about this very issue. I refer to a news item in the Age of 15 November, although the same matter was canvassed in other newspapers. It seems from that report that the Director of Public Prosecutions was himself in favour of the decriminalisation of hard drugs and that the Chairman of the National Crime Authority was not. I emphasise that I am basing this on the report, but it is plain from the terms of the report that the view of the person writing the report in the newspaper was that the Director of Public Prosecutions was in favour of the decriminalisation of hard drugs and that the Chairman of the National Crime Authority was not. Let me refer briefly to this newspaper item. It commences:
The Chairman of the National Crime Authority, Mr Peter Faris, QC, was in conflict last night-
last night being 14 November this year-
with the federal director of public prosecutions over laws used to fight organised crime.

Mr Faris said he disagreed with views expressed by the director, Mr Mark Weinberg, QC, on money laundering and the decriminalisation of drugs, and was likely to take up the matter with the federal Attorney-General, Mr Bowen.
It goes on to say of Mr Faris:
He said he wanted to know whether the Government intended to decriminalise hard drugs `as called for by the DPP'.
So it is quite plain that the view being attributed to Mr Faris is that Mr Weinberg's view is that there should be decriminalisation of hard drugs.

There are other differences of opinion between the two, so it would appear. But I want to emphasise the point that, on the basis of the report-and I certainly have not seen it denied-there is really a quite substantial difference of opinion between the two officers concerned. They are two senior law enforcement officers-probably the two most senior, subject to the Attorney-General himself-employed by the Commonwealth and, on this major issue of public policy, which is in fact directly addressed by the second reading speech, we find a very disturbing difference of opinion between the two of them.

What we want to know, especially in view of what has been put in the second reading speech, is whether the Director of Public Prosecutions, to use Mr Faris's words, has called for the decriminalisation of hard drugs. We want to know, to put it concisely, whether he has and, if so, what response has the Government given to him. It really is quite an extraordinary situation if the Commonwealth's senior prosecuting officer has called in effect for the negation of laws he is supposed to be enforcing. We are not saying, of course, that this is positively the view of the Director of Public Prosecutions; what we are saying is that the public controversy has arisen as a matter of fact-there can be no doubt about that-between the two of them, and we believe that it is the Attorney-General's responsibility on behalf of the Government to clarify this matter.

I might add, because it is relevant to the Bill and to the United Nations convention, that the same point applies to the dispute about money laundering. Mr Weinberg, as we understand him to be saying from the newspaper report, maintains that the Proceeds of Crime Act, which is a very important Act, is draconian. That is the word he used, apparently. On the other hand, Mr Faris says that the provisions should be tightened. He says that they are not draconian enough; that they should be much tougher. There is a body of opinion to the effect that we should have a much more stringent Proceeds of Crime Act. Apparently, that is the view held by Mr Faris.

What we want to know-indeed, the public has an entitlement to know this-is who is accurately expressing the Government's view in the first place and who is accurately expressing the view in so far as what happens on the ground is concerned? Is there any attitude of going soft on using the Proceeds of Crime Act because it is too draconian? Is there any lessening up in the efforts being used to pursue the money trail? Is there, as an alternative, any proposal to strengthen the Proceeds of Crime Act? It is a matter of debate. No doubt there are arguments on both sides, but the point remains that there is a difference of opinion which should be clarified.

This public disagreement between senior law enforcement officers is very unfortunate because it saps public confidence in law enforcement. Although these officers are, in the broad sense of the word, independent, there is an overriding responsibility on the Government to maintain public confidence in the fight against crime. One part of maintaining public confidence in the fight against crime is to satisfy people that the policy is clear, that the resources are there, that the attitude is there and that all officials have their heart in what they are doing and are vigorously and rigorously going to pursue and use the law which is there. It would be in the Government's own interests to have this difference of opinion resolved; as well as it being in the public interest to have this difference resolved.

Whatever the Government's position may be, the Opposition's position is quite clear because for our part we are opposed to this so-called notion of decriminalisation or legalisation of hard drugs. We believe that to embark on that course would be reckless in the extreme. It would create more drug addicts, it would do nothing for the present unfortunate victims of drugs, and it would create a new social problem of immense proportions. In addition to that, what is overlooked by those who advance the decriminalisation argument is that even if some drugs were `legalised' or `decriminalised', laws would still be needed to prevent illegal trafficking in heroin and also in other far more dangerous drugs which would still be illegal.

I cannot imagine any supporter of decriminalisation advocating that some of these completely illegal psychotropic substances should be legalised. Even if we decriminalised heroin, there would still be many illegal drugs and there would have to be laws to prevent their illegal traffic. What those who argue for decriminalisation overlook is that in that case we would still require laws and the enforcement of those laws. Surely it is not suggested that all narcotic and psychotropic drugs should be decriminalised or legalised. If it is not, stringent laws, matched with heavy penalities, will still be needed to stop the traffic in those particularly dangerous drugs.

We believe that the convention will provide a substantial weapon in the international fight against illegal trafficking in illegal drugs, but it will do that only if it is used and only if the Bill, when it becomes law, is used. If there is a single significant point above all that we want to make tonight, it is that we express the hope that the Bill, when it is passed, will be used. I say this because I am not convinced that the Government in all cases uses the powers that it has and I am not yet convinced that the Government will use all the powers that it will have under the Bill when it becomes law.

In particular, to use an analogy, I have noticed the grand proposition in the second reading speech that our extradition powers have been modernised, the implication being that this has brought about some new, extensive and vigorous use of extradition laws. It may be that the extradition laws have been modernised, but they have not always been put into practice. There is one case which is quite notorious where they have not been put into practice when clearly they should have been. The case I refer to is the Fiji arms cache incident of last year when the Government had a very clear case before it for using the extradition powers that it had. But it was, we believe, guilty then of the most spineless abrogation of responsibility, such that I wonder whether its heart is always in law enforcement of this international sort. In that case the Government seemed to think that its role was to discover reasons why extradition should not be used. It refused to extradite one of the miscreants to Fiji, where he should have been sent to stand trial, and it even refused to try to extradite the other miscreant from the United Kingdom to Australia to stand trial, although he was going around London-for all I know he is still doing so-telling anyone who cared to listen that he was responsible for the arms cache being imported into Australia.

It is interesting in that regard, because again it is reflected and picked up in the second reading speech to the Bill, to look back on the words of Senator Tate, the Minister for Justice, at the time we made our extradition arrangements with Fiji. He said that, as a result of the extradition arrangements that he was responsible for making with Fiji, neither Australia nor Fiji should become a haven for fugitives from justice. He went into some quite poetic flights on that occasion, before he went to Fiji and when he returned, painting this glowing picture of new extradition arrangements between Australian and Fiji and advancing the argument that now we had proper and efficient extradition arrangements between our two countries and the full rigour of the law would be used to ensure that criminals were brought to justice in the place where they should be put on trial and that would be done through the extradition arrangements that he had made.

He made those arrangements at about the time the Fijian arms cache was on the high seas. Little did he know-I presume that he knew little about it-that very shortly after that a wonderful opportunity would be presented to him for using those very extradition arrangements which he was heralding and lauding at that time. He said that the Fiji-Australia extradition arrangements would prevent Australia or Fiji being a haven for fugitives from justice. What a hollow threat that turned out to be because when an opportunity arose only a few months later to put those lofty propositions into practice, the Government simply threw in the towel and did nothing. To this day it has done next to nothing about the whole matter. It did not use the extradition powers that it had. The only consolation is that one day there will be proper enforcement and use of those powers in this country. So we reserve our view on whether the powers being given under the Bill will be used by the present Government. We support the Bill and simply say to the Government: when it becomes law, use it.

There is one final matter which is a little technical and I am sure that the Attorney-General will be able to assist us. It seems to have been an oversight, although it may not be. I am sure the Attorney-General will be able to throw some light on it. I ask him whether there should not be in the Bill some provision by which the Proceeds of Crime Act, the Extradition Act and the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act are used. We are creating new offences under the Bill and the question arises as to whether those offences are subject to the machinery provisions of the Proceeds of Crime Act. We hope that they are. We would support any move to ensure and guarantee that they are. But are those new offences subject to the machinery set up under the Extradition Act. Are they subject to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act? The Bill is silent on this. It seems to us, on reading it, that there may well be a need for some expansion of its provisions. So we simply ask, in a constructive sense, whether there is a gap there, and perhaps we may get some explanation for that.

Above all in this debate, we want to make the basic point that this is an important convention, because the traffic in illegal drugs is one of the great evils facing the world today. We believe that the international nature of the convention is such that it will probably turn out to be a very effective weapon indeed in stamping out the international traffic in illegal narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances. We support the convention. We support the Bill. We reject this notion that seems to be becoming the fashion of the times that we should be looking at decriminalisation and legalisation. That is not going to solve anything. That is probably going to create a greater evil than the evil we have at the moment. We simply say to the Government that we are giving it these powers under the Bill, which we are now supporting, and expect it to use the powers to their full extent as part of its ongoing fight against the international traffic in illegal drugs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I make some comments in support of the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Bill, I wish to pick up a couple of observations made by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown). I think that he is to be commended for his speech in the second reading debate tonight. We welcome the fact that, for once, the Opposition is accepting legislation that has been put forward by the Government and is not simply opposing legislation for the sake of opposing it. That is a very rare but pleasurable occurrence in this House. I thought that the contribution the honourable member for Menzies made in discussing the Bill was considered, and I commend him for it. I do not agree with a number of the things the honourable member for Menzies said, but he raised matters that are at the core of quite wide debate in the community and some disagreement is to be expected in some of the points he put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: One matter on which I take issue with the honourable member for Menzies is his attempt to make something of the fact that the Director of Public Prosecutions might have a particular view on the application of the Proceeds of Crimes Act and other matters raised by the honourable member for Menzies, and that the Chairman of the National Crime Authority (NCA) might have a different view. The honourable member for Menzies then said that some clarification needed to be made by the Government as these two officers should not be at odds and expressing different views because of the effect on confidence in law enforcement. This is where I take issue with the honourable member for Menzies. He has been around for a long time and knows that these two officers are very senior Commonwealth appointees and are expected to carry out their duties independently of each other and have views independent of the Government. They are certainly not expected to be out there simply putting forward the Government's view on particular matters, and especially matters as substantial as these. In other words, no-one expects them to express the Government's view. It is a matter for debate. They are paid to do a job.

The National Crime Authority has four terms of reference, and the Chairman of the NCA is paid to carry out the responsibilities of the NCA, which are, in part, to make sure that the NCA meets its obligations under the Act. Part of its obligation is to give advice to the Government on strategies that ought to be adopted in the national fight against organised crime, to give advice and direction to the Government on where it ought be looking at changes in practices or in legislation. That is the role of the NCA. The Director of Public Prosecutions has an entirely different role, as the honourable member for Menzies well knows-and I do not need to spell these things out to him-which is independently to assess the evidence, assess the case, set about prosecuting the case and make judgments about prosecutions. It is very clear that they will have different views about these things.

I turn to the proceeds of crime approach and in fact the broader approach that the National Crime Authority is now taking in its linked activities with the Australian Taxation Office. Mr Faris is quite openly saying the strategy is now being adopted of following the money trial. It is very difficult to catch these very practised, skilled and intelligent criminal organisations in an illegal act. All sorts of government techniques have been tried in all sorts of countries over a long period to try to catch these organisations in an illegal act. But it is difficult to trace the proceeds of crime and use other avenues via the tax Act to point up criminality and approach the problem in a different way. I suppose it is a lesson that many of us should have learnt from the experience in the United States with A1 Capone 60 years ago.

In Victoria-and I very much welcome this-we have seen the Australian Taxation Office and the National Crime Authority acting in collaboration in the raids in Mildura last week. One cannot comment about the possible outcome of those raids, but very clearly we are seeing a cooperative action between the Tax Office, which has identified particular targets, and the NCA, which has identified the same targets but in its own field. I would like to see that cooperative approach continuing.

The point on which I take issue with the honourable member for Menzies is that one cannot come into the House and try to make out that there is some sort of difficult conflict going on in law enforcement circles when the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Chairman of the NCA have differing views about the degree of application of particular measures. They are expected to carry out their duties independently, not only of the Government but of each other, and it is not surprising that they do have different views.

As the honourable member for Menzies has properly said, the Bill is something of a landmark in legislation in Australia and in the fight against crime and narcotic drugs. As the honourable member noted, it brings the Commonwealth Government's obligations into line with the United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances which is part of an international commitment by the developed countries for a cooperative approach to this world-wide problem of illicit drug traffic. As the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons) made clear in his second reading speech, article 4 of the convention requires a number of areas of extended jurisdiction to be created, which I certainly welcome. For instance, where an Australian national engages in conduct outside Australia which is an offence under the convention, we will have jurisdiction. I note, too, that there is provision under the convention for us to have reservations about extraditing a national of another country to that country if we do not secure satisfactory undertakings about the likely penalties that might be applied. Those sorts of practices are to be welcomed and are part of a broader international approach which I certainly support.

I also take up some of the comments made by the honourable member for Menzies on the question of decriminalisation. He devoted quite a bit of time to the issue of whether the Government ought to be looking at decriminalisation. He was putting a very strong view that we should not and that we should maintain prohibition. He raised this issue, I acknowledge, because nothing in the Convention prevents governments which are parties to the Convention going down the road of decriminalisation.

As a member of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, which oversees the operations of the National Crime Authority, I was party to a report which was tabled in the House a couple of months ago and which the Attorney-General is considering at the moment. Among other things, that report has set the parameters for genuine consideration in this country of the issue of decriminalisation. It was handed down by my colleague the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), who is the Chairman of the Committee, and it was entitled Drugs and Crime in Society. That report essentially has tried to examine, first of all, whether we have been successful in the fight against organised crime and whether decriminalisation in the end is the approach that needs to be followed. It has set out parameters by which a further judgment can be made, and it is recommended that that should be in about three years time. For the first time a set of criteria has been laid out by which we can ask whether we are succeeding. If we are not succeeding, we have to look at other options.

The report really brings the debate very close to its final stages of conclusion in this country. I believe that all Western nations must now be aware that prohibition does not work. Whether the issue is prostitution, gambling, trafficking in drugs or sale of alcohol, there is no significant evidence that I know of in any country that prohibition actually works. I take the view that the issue of decriminalisation will have to be faced down the road and I think that this report has set out the relevant parameters very well.

Another very interesting aspect of the report concerns its two principal recommendations. The honourable member for Menzies tried earlier to make something of the conflict between key approaches and the fact that this conflict might be undermining public confidence in the fight against crime. We also had some conflict regarding the handing down of the conclusions of the report that the honourable member for McEwen tabled. The two principal recommendations fit very closely with the United Nations Convention. They really address the question of education, particularly among young people, and perceptions in the community. They join with the general theme of the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse, which, of course, concerns awareness and education.

The principal recommendation was that the Government consider seriously the means by which we could bring about a ban on the advertising of alcohol and tobacco products. The reasoning behind that recommendation was that when one talks to young people in particular about the immorality and dangers of what they see as perhaps their drug area-particularly cannabis-the first thing they do is say, `What about grog and smokes? They are the things that are causing all the health problems in the community. If you are going to ban our stuff, why won't you ban your own? If you are going to talk about advertising and promotion, why don't you take your own drugs seriously?'. That is what young people actually think and say.

The members of our Committee, from both sides, were quite comfortable about these recommendations until it came to the crunch of actually putting the name on the dotted line, particularly in relation to the banning of alcohol. I do not need to raise in the House the links those opposite have with certain figures who are key brewers in this country. But we came up with a finding which was supported. Members of the Liberal Party of Australia were prepared to support a ban on tobacco advertising but they were not prepared to support a ban on alcohol advertising. One is entitled to ask who is pulling strings and why they would not support such a ban when during the processes of consideration this did not seem to be a problem. There is some genuine conflict there. The issue of who is pulling the strings, who is determining policies and whose interests are really at stake when one considers banning the advertising of alcohol products, are matters that have been raised elsewhere. That is something that the honourable member for Menzies might like to discuss in his own party room.

I also say to the honourable member for Menzies that there is a need to overhaul the law in a number of ways. As a Queen's Counsel, he ought to know that and he ought to know also that there are many lawyers in this Parliament and that they generally tend to be very conservative about law reform. Not the least conservative are those in the Opposition who go around preaching these views until it comes to the crunch of actually changing some of the techniques. Honourable members should look at the proposal that we consider scrapping committal hearings. Why do we not get down to the crunch and start making some recommendations? If we did, conservative lawyers opposite would come right out of the woodwork to oppose such a measure because genuine law reform which actually brings the law a bit closer to ordinary people is not very high on the agenda. As the recent report says, justice delayed is justice denied. It is very interesting to see the long heritage of conservatism in the field of law reform, particularly from those on the other side of the House who have had so much time and opportunity to do something about these things.

I have wandered a bit from the specific points that I intended to talk about in relation to the Bill but I was drawn into debating the points that the honourable member for Menzies made. I repeat that, certainly from my point of view, we on the Government side welcome the fact that the Opposition supports the legislation and is not again going down the road of opposition for the sake of opposition. We all welcome the United Nations Convention and the cooperative approach of all countries to it. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following on from the comments of the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), I was particularly interested in the latter portions of his address to the House this evening and some of the comments which he made in relation to the decriminalisation of certain drugs. I paid particular attention to his comments that around the world there is no evidence that, by making the taking of drugs illegal, one actually stops people participating in drug taking. By making drugs illegal one will not stop people participating in drug taking. But if we follow the argument that the honourable member for Burke has put-that, because there is no evidence anywhere in the world that people are discouraged from taking drugs by making the taking of drugs illegal, it is therefore worthwhile making it legal-we can apply that argument to virtually every crime that we have on the statute books today. We could say that by making, say, murder illegal we have not stopped murders occurring in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The argument that was extended by the honourable member for Burke was that, because it is illegal to take drugs in countries around the world but people are still taking drugs, therefore it is a good argument to get rid of the illegal aspects of the taking of drugs and make them legal. I am afraid that that argument does not hold a lot of sense or logic for me. Indeed, if one looks around the world at countries which have tried to decriminalise or legitimate the use of drugs, one will find that that has not solved the problem. No matter where one looks, one finds that if drugs are decriminalised there is still an illegal element, a criminal element, in the sale and distribution of drugs. One finds that rather than drug participation decreasing it actually gets worse.

People such as the honourable member for Burke who say that if we decriminalise drugs tomorrow we will reduce the problem, get rid of the criminal aspect, are really not at all realistic. They are certainly not very practical. They look at the argument from one side only and do not consider the fact that in countries that have experimented with the decriminalisation of various drugs, there has been no beneficial effect whatsoever.

It is also quite a nonsense for people to say that because it is legal to drink alcohol, it should be reasonable to expect it to be legal to take drugs. Honourable members on this side of the House would be very much aware of the fact that in this country it is illegal to consume in excess of a certain amount of alcohol. If one does consume in excess of a certain amount of alcohol and gets caught, one is brought before the law and punished in a proper and due manner. I am bringing to the attention of members of this House the fact that a certain partaking of alcohol is illegal, so it is not correct to say that because alcohol is legal drugs should be legal. Alcohol consumption in excess of a prescribed amount is illegal. The argument put forward is a complete and utter nonsense. If one were to look at the deleterious effects that drug taking has on the human body and on the mind one would agree that it is a far more dangerous and far less socially acceptable activity than are the normal social drinking habits that most Australians engage in in the course of their daily lives.

I find the arguments put forward by the honourable member for Burke unreasonable, unrealistic and indeed quite a nonsense. It is simply not good enough to say that because in countries where drugs have been made illegal drugs are still being taken, this is evidence that we should not continue to make drugs illegal. It is a nonsense. It is also a nonsense to say that because alcohol is legal in this country we should also make drugs legal. This problem concerns millions of Australians. The matter before the House tonight goes very much to the heart and mind of the ordinary Australian. It is a problem which has got worse over the years and it will continue to get worse unless we are prepared to have legislation such as the Bill we have before the House tonight. It will get worse unless we, as a society, are prepared to tackle this issue in a more serious fashion. It will get worse unless we, as a government and as a society, are prepared to put more resources towards overcoming the problem.

If one wants to see how bad drugs in Australia can get one has only to travel to countries such as the United States of America, where the drug problem is really getting out of hand. It is taking over the lives of many very good young Americans. It is taking up a great deal of America's crime fighting resources. It is taking up the resources of the courts and the legal system. The problem in the United States is really quite alarming. It is getting worse and it is an indicator of what can happen here in Australia unless we are prepared to address the matter in a proper, responsible fashion.

This Bill does address some matters which honourable members on this side of the House believe need to be addressed. Many Bills such as this need to be introduced into the Parliament before we can properly overcome all of the deficiencies in our legal system. Two or three years ago I had a far more active role in matters pertaining to drugs. At the time there were a number of loopholes in our legal system. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) would possibly remember the Tailon case, which involved, I think, a Canadian person transiting through Australia on his way to Canada. He was caught having in his possession some drugs, I think cocaine, in a video unit. The law said that because he was in transit he was not theoretically in Australia; therefore the law enforcement agencies in Australia were not able to apprehend him despite the fact that it was known that he was in possession of a substantial quantity of these drugs. Those sorts of loopholes are evidence of the fact that we have many problems to overcome. I know the Attorney-General has done some work to try to overcome them in the future.

We have many loopholes in our system today. One can become quite alarmed when looking at the laws that differ between the States. From State to State, laws that relate to drug crimes differ quite substantially. In fact, people who engage in the selling and distribution of drugs may find it easier to live in a particular State simply because the laws in that State are more lenient or make apprehension more difficult. If one is apprehended the penalties that apply may be much less in a particular State in Australia. So the argument could be put-and I believe quite reasonably-that there is a need for more uniform laws around Australia. We should get the States to cooperate so that there is no difference, from one State to the other, in terms of the law's application to those people who try to break our drug codes.

There are also some deficiencies in the legal weapons we give some of our law enforcement officers. Three or four years ago I remember raising in the House the fact that argentine ant inspectors theoretically had more powers than officers of the National Crime Authority in the course of investigating a suspected drug crime. In fact, at the time an argentine ant inspector could march into anybody's house or premises and carry out an inspection if he or she had reasonable grounds to suspect that argentine ants were on the premises. At the time, National Crime Authority drug agents were not able to enter premises if they had reasonable grounds to suspect that somebody in those premises may have been in possession of drugs. These sorts of differences highlight the fact that those who are given the task of capturing people who engage in the drug business feel very frustrated because sometimes they do not have the necessary legal powers to carry out the job in the manner in which they see fit. Many people on this side of the House would say that in order to overcome the problem I have just highlighted we may have to go a little bit too far and be a little too draconian. I raise the matter not seriously believing it can be addressed tonight or in the near future but to highlight to the House the frustrations and difficulties many people who are given the task of carrying out law enforcement in this country have to face.

One of the other improvements in recent years-it has come from the Attorney- General, who is sitting opposite-has been in the telephone tapping power. This has been a welcome and useful tool that our law enforcement agents have had to try to capture people engaged in the business of selling and distributing drugs. Telephones are a means of communication which people engaged in this business have in the past believed to be a fairly secure means of communication. This power has been a very useful weapon in catching these people.

I, like the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), have been disturbed by recent arguments put forward by senior Commonwealth officers that indicate that we should decriminalise some drugs. The honourable member for Menzies mentioned the Director of Public Prosecutions. The comments made by him in a recent conference draw concern not only from me and the honourable member for Menzies but from many reasonable Australians simply because here we have a senior Commonwealth legal officer who has, according to newspaper reports, been espousing the decriminalising of a number of drugs. This not only causes confusion and alarm but also places pressure on the Government to make a clear and definite statement about its opinions in this area. I believe that there is a need for the Government to show true leadership in this matter and for the Attorney-General to give his views on this point tonight. I do not think it is right or proper that comments such as those made by the Director of Public Prosecutions should be allowed to go without some sort of clarifying statement from the Attorney-General. We look forward to those comments.

I believe that many people who engage in this debate about legalisation of drugs often have not had to work at the coalface of the drug industry. They are often the people who talk on the cocktail circuit. It is a trendy, pseudo-intellectual subject and a person's alleged superior intellect can be established simply by discussing something that is controversial, radical and somewhat different. Those people, whom we hear every couple of weeks on television and talkback radio shows, espouse the argument that we should decriminalise drugs without really understanding what they are talking about.

As I mentioned, in my early parliamentary career I had an opportunity over a period of about two years to talk to a lot of people who work at the coalface of the drug problem in this country. I found that, almost to a man, those people who work there urged us not to get into the business of decriminalising drugs. I often asked the question, `Do you think we should decriminalise drugs?', and they said, `No, definitely not; it would only make the situation worse'. I believe that the views of those people who work at the coalface should be taken into consideration. The people who often espouse the decriminalisation of these drugs have very rarely had any contact with the problem at the coalface. I therefore do not believe that we should give any credibility to their views because they really do not know what they are talking about.

I believe that those who say we should decriminalise drugs are wrong. By decriminalising drugs, we would introduce into our society another vice that we cannot live with, do not need and could not handle. Society has enough vice problems with which to deal at the moment. Those problems are difficult enough to deal with now. It would make it almost impossible for parents throughout Australia and for people in positions of responsibility to try to persuade young Australians that it was wrong to take drugs if those young Australians were able to say, `It is legal to take drugs, therefore the Government must think that it is all right, therefore society must think that it is all right. Because of those things, we will take those drugs'.

Society and governments must show some leadership. They must set an example and I believe that the best way to set an example, to show how society reacts to something, to show what a society thinks of something, is to show people that we reject it by making it illegal. That course of action helps the task of many parents in this country who are trying to control their children as they grow up. It also helps to control people in the broader sections of our society because, without that sort of legal backup, it is very difficult for authorities to implement proper and decent standards in our society. If people want to talk about solving the drug problem, there are ways to do it. They are long term rather than short overnight cures, but there are ways to overcome the problem. I believe that Australia does not use the facility of education properly. We have some very good education programs which are still not properly utilised in our schools and various community groups. I have been involved with the life education centres which were set up by the Reverend Ted Noffs at the Wayside Chapel some years ago. Life education centres are very useful tools to help educate young people in our schools. However, they are not the complete answer to the problem.

This year I visited the United States of America where I saw a very successful scheme called DARE, which was originally established by the Los Angeles Police Department. I believe that if life education centres were complemented with the DARE program, we would probably have the best education program available in the world today. Proper education of our young people will help to reduce the drug problem in Australia in the long term. The energies and efforts that are put into the arguments as to why we should decriminalise drugs would be better directed towards this argument. If all those people who sat around at cocktail parties directed their energies and efforts to this problem perhaps by raising some money and gaining community and government support for more resources towards the education of our young people in relation to the dangers and problems of drugs, then those people would do the world a great deal of good.

I believe that we must increase our efforts. We must coordinate our law enforcement bodies throughout Australia. So many law enforcement bodies have a role to play in the detection of drug problems and drug trafficking, but they are not properly coordinated. I have seen examples where three or four officers from different drug enforcement agencies have all been involved in the one case but have not communicated properly with each other. As a result, the very limited resources of governments are wasted. We must have better intelligence. I commend Mr Newman, I think it was, who in the Fraser Government was the Minister for Administrative Services and who set up Australian Federal Police officers in some of these drug capitals around the world to feed back advanced intelligence to Australia in order to warn us of possible drug shipments into this country. Those people have been very useful indeed and have helped to deal very effectively with drug trafficking from those countries. We must use more methods like that.

We must become more involved in the world's cooperative effort to reduce drug trafficking. We were involved with 12 other nations in the crop replacement program in Thailand. That is a good program which will be slow to get going, but it will have some long term benefits. We must be prepared to do more in this country about extraditions so that, when possible, we can cooperate with our colleagues around the world in capturing people and sending them home or bringing them back to our country when they participate in drug trafficking. If we are prepared to do those things and take a long view of the solution to the drug problem, then I believe that in 10, 15 or 20 years time we will actually come to grips with the problem and start to reduce it. However, decriminalising drugs will only make the problem worse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a wonderful, simple world it must be in the electorate of Gilmore. We have heard some of the most extraordinary propositions that I can recall being expressed in this chamber. It was proposed that, by an edict of this Parliament, we will somehow affect the behaviour of people to such an extent that we will eliminate a problem that most people in our community regard as one of the most singularly pressing issues of our age. I do not accept that analysis and I do not think it is only the cocktail set who would also disagree with it. I fear that the reservations about the kinds of simplistic propositions put forward by the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) are shared by people who would not normally be thought of as members of the cocktail set cognoscenti.

SPEECH.PARA: They include, for example, the Police Commissioner of New South Wales, Mr Avery, who has expressed real concern as to whether or not we should look at amending our social policy with respect to how we respond to the question of drugs in our society. They include the Deputy Commissioner of the Victoria Police, Mr Delianis, and Mr Justice Fox, and I will return to his comments shortly. They include Senator Peter Baume, the colleague in the Senate of the honourable member for Gilmore, and the whole membership of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, which reported to both the House of Representatives and the Senate earlier this year and was chaired by the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland). I will refer to that detailed report shortly.

Unfortunately, this is not an issue upon which we would be wise to rely on shibboleths or simple assertions of propositions that are undeniably false. The propositions put forward by the honourable member for Gilmore were undeniably false. (Quorum formed) Undeniably true it is that the present policy that has been in operation in Australia has failed by way of prescription of legal norms to staunch the use of illegal drugs in our society.

I turn to the specifics of the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Bill. I raise no objections to it and recognise the merits of most of the proposals in the Bill in terms of making sure that the procedures that exist in Australia to control the domestic trafficking of drugs and to prohibit it are extended, so that it is impossible to slide outside their ambit by engaging in conduct in other countries. The measures included in the Bill will be of considerable value in terms of making arrangements for the prosecution of those who are involved in overseas transactions in relation to drugs and making certain that we are not without the legal means to reach out to Australian subjects, even those who are out of the country, who are engaged in trafficking. To that extent, I welcome the initiatives in the Bill, but I also want to express some serious concerns about the schedule that is attached to the Bill because I do not believe that either on constitutional grounds or as a matter of necessity that schedule should exist.

I raise some concerns about the schedule because I believe that it presages, it leads to, the likely ratification in due course of the third United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. That is a matter of concern because it would seem to me to rule out options which both sides of the House say should at least be considered. It is premature for anybody in the Parliament to say that it is time to abandon the policing methods that we have applied in the past and move to an entirely new model, yet we are being consistently challenged to look at our practices and approaches by people who are entirely responsible in the field of policing and in the field of treatment and control of drugs.

We are also being challenged to think about these issues by our members. Some members have taken a very bold position in relation to this issue. For example, Senator Peter Baume has come forward and led a public debate arguing that a wide variety of drugs that are presently illegal in our society should be made freely available. That is not a view that yet commends itself to me, but certainly it seems that we need to do more than have a knee-jerk response to some of these issues and that the very real options that we are being asked to consider by responsible leaders in the law area require some substantive response.

Why does the schedule to the Bill provide some concern to a number of people who are in expert positions to comment in relation to this area? The first reason is that the schedule provides that each state party, subject to its constitutional principles and basic concepts of its legal system, shall adopt such measures as may be necessary to establish as a criminal offence under its domestic law, when committed intentionally, the possession, purchase or cultivation of narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances for personal consumption, contrary to the provisions of the 1961 convention. On its face, that would seem to exclude the possibility of there being any consideration subsequently in Australia-without breach of our international obligations, if this is adopted-of a different response, a response where, for example, it might be permitted to have personal possession and use of, say, small amounts of marijuana.

The complexity of the issue is compounded by the fact that the convention deals with marijuana as a narcotic drug and treats it in the same manner as a range of other drugs which we now commonly regard as of a greater degree of addictive or dangerous quality. For example, we find in the list of narcotic drugs in schedule 2 annexed to the Bill drugs such as benzethidine cocaine and dihydromorphine and various other drugs which are obviously very potent, as well as cannabis. That obviously presents us with some difficulty if we are looking at this from society's point of view because there is no doubt that, although it is not a widely held view, there is a substantial body of opinion in our society that holds a view that possession of a small amount of cannabis should not be treated in the same way as possession of other drugs. Again, this is not a matter upon which one needs to hold any concluded view, but it is no doubt the point-and surveys show it-that many Australians have used cannabis and that there is some degree of hypocrisy. What the report entitled Drugs, Crime and Society by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority puts forward is, in a sense, a tacit program of decriminalisation by neglect, as it were.

The problem with the convention is that it does not permit us to look at the possible options that many commentators raise. For example, the Police Commissioner in New South Wales and the Deputy Police Commissioner in Victoria have both said that the policing cost of making narcotic drugs illegal is a cost which impacts on the force, in terms of both corruption and the social cost to many in society, to a degree such that we should consider the alternatives.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

—Mr Speaker, I rise tonight because a constituent of mine has drawn my attention to a matter of considerable inconvenience caused to him by a lack of cooperation between the National Acoustics Laboratory and a major public hospital. I raise this in the adjournment debate in the hope that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) will review what is clearly an unsatisfactory arrangement. My constituent must wear a hearing aid because of a war service disability. He is still working, and this makes the use of a hearing aid of vital importance to him in his working environment. On 20 October this year his hearing was tested at Concord Repatriation General Hospital, where the audiobiologist advised that a new and more powerful hearing aid was needed. The audiobiologist telephoned the National Acoustics Laboratory at Chatswood to make arrangements for the supply of a new aid, and was told that my constituent would have to be re-tested by its own staff. However, he was told that, due to staff shortages, this could not be done for at least six months. The Concord audiobiologist offered to send his test results to the National Acoustics Laboratory in order to reduce the six months delay, but was informed that his tests were not acceptable to the laboratory and that re-testing by its own staff was necessary. The Concord audiobiologist admitted to my constituent that he has encountered this difficulty before and that he has, unsuccessfully, written to the Minister pointing to the delays and inconvenience which this double testing requirement is imposing on its patients.

SPEECH.PARA: If the shortage of staff at the National Acoustics Laboratory was of a short-term nature, I could be tolerant of circumstances which might be causing a temporary blow-out of its waiting lists. But the staff shortages are apparently of a long-standing nature, and a long waiting list is the rule rather than the exception. Under these circumstances I would have thought that the National Acoustics Laboratory would have welcomed revised testing arrangements which took the pressure off its own resources, reduced its waiting lists, and provided a more acceptable service to the public. If there is a serious shortage of audiobiologists, or the National Acoustics Laboratory is having difficulty in attracting their employment, why are we persevering with a system which is forcing patients to be tested twice? Surely the circumstances cry out for a little bit of commonsense, where the laboratory accepts the test results of approved or accredited audiobiologists in other institutions or practices.

I would be happy to provide the Minister with the name and address of my constituent, and to do so in the hope that his community action in bringing this matter to my attention will assist those people with hearing defects who are presently being inconvenienced by long and unnecessary delays in having their hearing tested by the National Acoustics Laboratory. My constituent has a disability caused by war service. One would have hoped that this Government would, as any government should, take that into account and that we would have a more sensible approach to what is obviously a matter of great importance to this constituent. It is of great importance because his very livelihood depends upon his being able to hear and to respond in his dealings with his clients. But what we have is a bureaucratic mess which has been drawn to the attention of the Minister by those people working in his own Department. From what I hear of it, the Minister, as is not unusual for this Minister, has taken absolutely no notice whatsoever. The situation simply is not good enough and something should be done about it, not just at some time in the future but immediately.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Saturday the people of South Australia were asked to send a message to Canberra, and they did just that, loud and clear. They are fed up with this Government's high interest rate policy. Today in debate the Government sought comfort from the fact that, whilst there was a swing away from Labor, nevertheless it appears to have won the election. Let me set the record straight. SPEECH.PARA: The undeniable fact is that the people reject this Government's economic policies and its inability to deal with the basic problems confronting the nation. South Australia has given the thumbs down to the Hawke Government. Whilst many overseas countries are enjoying quite rapid rates of growth and are tailoring their economic policies to cope with that growth, our Treasurer (Mr Keating) is trying to choke off our growth while leaving his other hopelessly outdated policies in place. Why is growth good for overseas nations but bad for Australia? Of course it is not, but the Labor Government cannot bring itself to relax the rigid controls on our economy to allow it to cope with more rapid growth without generating higher inflation or balance of payment problems.

I believe Garnaut got it right in highlighting the need to deregulate, internationalise our economy and achieve a level playing field. We have already lost valuable time and as a result are losing our competitive edge. The rapid rate of innovation and change in our major competitor nations is leaving us in Australia for dead. We cannot afford to wait any longer. I acknowledge that the Government started to make the changes required by floating the Australian dollar and freeing up the banking sector, but then it dropped the ball. For example, how on earth can Australia hope to compete internationally when our waterfront is more suited to clippers than container ships? We will get nowhere until we have a basic restructuring of the waterfront, including the introduction of truly competitive stevedoring companies with their own work force. How can Australia compete internationally when we have so many of our resources tied up in Government-run enterprises, protected from competition and adding to our basic costs of production?

Nearly every Western country in the world has seen the benefit of transferring public sector activities into the private sector. The results have been increased competition and efficiency with lower prices, wider choice and better services for consumers, and greater rewards and job satisfaction for employees. The economy also benefits through higher returns on the capital employed in the privatised industry. The United Kingdom led the charge, and almost everybody is following-Canada, Japan, New Zealand, even the Soviet Union, but not the Hawke Government. Privatisation has revolutionised Britain, resulting in less regulation, lower cost services and greater innovation. Since British Telecom has been privatised its profits have risen and the service improved. A competitor has been established and the consumer is the great beneficiary in the form of lower costs, today even to the extent of being offered free mobile phones. The communications revolution is booming in the deregulated economies of the world. While overseas business is continually confronted by and is adapting to these new technological advances, we bumble along in our heavily regulated and controlled cocoon.

The wages accord is yet another example of the Government's outdated thinking. Everyone knows that we have to have greater flexibility and responsibility in our wages system. The Business Council of Australia says we can have efficiency gains of up to 25 per cent if we move to enterprise-based industrial relations, but not the Hawke Government. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Direct marketing is one of the most effective means of retailing in modern society. It is a very useful method of purchase for those who live in isolated areas, those who are housebound, those who are handicapped and those who are elderly. Direct marketing has become a very important means of retailing through television, the post and radio. We have ongoing promotions of people having this direct contact from the retailer to the consumer without going through the normal retail house. It has resulted in our being inundated with unsolicited mail to the point that it has now spread not only to mail but also to facsimile messages and I was pleased that the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mrs Kelly) acted today to try to do something about fax machines being clogged.

SPEECH.PARA: This technique is used not only in the direct marketing of merchandise; it is used also by charities and all sorts of groups trying to raise money. It has led also to a new enterprise, and that is list brokering. The direct marketing directory of 1989 which is put out by the Direct Marketing Association includes all sorts of groups in the list brokering side. For instance, one group is called Drake List Management and another Dun and Bradstreet (Australia) Pty Ltd. Surprisingly, another group is called Logos Foundation. Another is called Logos List Services. Recently I wrote to all of these groups asking that they please advise as to their activities because children of nine years of age are receiving lottery tickets, and material coming from Madam Daudet in the United States is getting children to sign oaths of secrecy and then, for $30, sending them her Golden Wave which will change their love life and their riches.

Someone in this country is selling those lists of children, because children of 10 and 11 years of age are getting these letters. I have some with me which I will not table because I will be sending them to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. They are coming from somewhere and I have appealed to the list brokers to set some new standards. I looked up the material published by the Logos Foundation the other day, and there is nothing on its material which has been circulated throughout Queensland in recent weeks to say that, if anyone subscribes to the letter this Foundation is asking them to, his name shall be used and his name and address shall be sold. I have spoken to some of the charity heads, asking them to desist from sending nine-year-old children art union and lottery tickets. But I think we need to call upon the industry to set its own standards. No person should have his name or address sold without prior consent or approval and no child should be targeted or put on these lists without parental consent. I do not know whether the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) would agree with that, but I would suggest that most members of this Parliament would say, `We have to put an end to the targeting of children'.

We also have to do something to upgrade and protect the rights of individuals, the rights of privacy. Any member of parliament and any citizen will know that when one goes to one's mail box it is clogged up with mail that one did not ask for. In many instances it is because one's name has been sold without one's permission. This will be the marketing method of the future. But if that is the case, we need rules for the future. We need the Logos Foundation-I did not know it was involved in this-the Logos List Services and all these many other listed on page seven of this directory and the hundreds of others that are listed that are buying and collecting lists of people, to have some tough standards.

I met with Greg Baker, the general head of Australian Direct Marketing, the other day in the Parliament. That company is going to bring down some new rules. But that will only work if we as a parliament and the other legislatures throughout this nation are also prepared to enforce the rules, if necessary, by legislation. We have to ensure that list brokers are sticking to standards. We have to ensure that those who collect the names of people get their permission. We have to ensure that we do something about the Madam Daudets and all these others who come out of New Jersey and California who are targeting Australians and asking them to send money to phoney lotteries.

I suggest that this is the sort of thing that needs a full and thorough inquiry. It is the sort of thing that should be referred eventually to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs to try to come up with what we would see as uniform laws and protection. In the meantime, I appeal to those who are involved-the list brokers and the direct marketing merchandisers-to set some standards, to stop targeting children and to ensure that they have obtained the prior permission of the people whose names are listed. I suppose it is fair play that, if people write away for some project, they should expect some like product coming back to them. But it is wrong, it is immoral and it is insidious that kids of nine, 10 and 11 are receiving art union tickets, their names are being listed and their addresses are being sold. This Parliament needs to do something about it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 26 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do orders, rules or regulations of the Federal Court permit plaintiff election of a jury in matters relevant to the Trade Practices Act; if so, have juries ever been appointed in such matters by the Federal Court in Melbourne.
(2) If juries are permitted, is their use discouraged by the Federal Court; if so, why.
(3) If juries are not permitted, will consideration be given to amending the orders, rules or regulations so as to permit juries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 does not permit plaintiff election of a jury in suits before the Federal Court. Section 39 of the Act provides that in every suit in the Court, unless the Court or a Judge otherwise orders, the trial shall be by a Judge without a jury. Section 40 of the Act enables the Court or a Judge, in any suit in which the ends of justice appear to render it expedient to do so, to direct the trial with a jury of the suit or of an issue of fact. A direction for a trial with a jury has not been made in any matter relevant to the Trade Practices Act by the Federal Court in Melbourne.

(2) The Federal Court has held, in Insurance Commissioner v. Australian Associated Motor Insurers Ltd (1982) 65 FLR 172, that before a direction is made for a trial with a jury, some substantial reason must be shown for a departure from the normal method of trial in the Federal Court of trial by a Judge without a jury.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 31 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the Medical Letter of 28 September 1989 that his Department is pressing for the cessation of Medicare rebates for pathology and radiology services rendered by general practitioners.
(2) Is such a course of action being considered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) There are no plans to make any changes to the existing arrangements covering the provision of pathology services by general practitioners. Action is to be taken, however, to impose controls on the provision of diagnostic imaging services. These services cover diagnostic radiology, CT scanning, ultrasound, magnetic resonance imaging, and nuclear scanning.

The control measures, which have been recommended by a Department Diagnostic Imaging Services Review, include the proposed introduction of an ``arms length'' referral arrangement in the provision of imaging services. This would be effected by specifying that Medicare benefits are generally not payable for these services unless they have been requested by another practitioner who has no direct financial interest in the ordering of those services.

I approved the establishment of the Review in 1987 because of concern about the rate of growth in the utilisation of diagnostic imaging services and because it was claimed, particularly by the Royal Australasian College of Radiologists, that much of this growth could be attributed to the activities of certain medical entrepreneurs. These practitioners purchased imaging equipment with a view to maximising income.

The measures recommended by the Review seek to ensure that there is a financial distance between the providers and requesters of diagnostic imaging services. In this regard, they address the relationship which is expected between practitioners providing services and referring practitioners, technicians (e.g. radiographers), and the owners of imaging equipment and medical centres. They also call for compliance with State licensing laws and specify action that should be taken in respect of any breaches. In essence, the control measures seek to impose restrictions similar to those which have applied to pathology services for some time.

It should be noted, however, that the Review recognised that strict referral arrangements posed potential problems in remote areas. Accordingly, to ensure that access to necessary services would not be denied, it recommended that the proposed referral requirements not apply in remote areas where there is no other practitioner equipped or able to provide services and where visiting services, if any, cannot adequately meet the needs of the community. Although further discussions will be needed to determine exactly how this exemption should operate, the Government is committed to the implementation of the Review's recommendations.

Also excluded from the referral arrangements will be those radiology services which have historically been seen as falling within the competence of general practitioners and which have been specified in the Medicare Benefits Schedule as non-specialist services. These include X-rays of the extremities, shoulder, chest and abdomen.

It is regrettable that curbing the activities of the unscrupulous elements of the medical profession necessarily impacts on responsible practitioners but, as in the pathology area, the Government believes that it has an obligation to take all reasonable steps to prevent the manipulation of the benefits arrangements.
